docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
Time: ~5 minutes | Level: Beginner

This guide walks you through installing flow-cli and verifying it works.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, verify you have:

# Check ZSH (required)
zsh --version
# Expected: zsh 5.8 or higher

# Check Git (required)
git --version
# Expected: any recent version

docs.title: Homebrew (Recommended for macOS)
docs.text:
The easiest installation method for macOS users:

# 1. Tap the repository
brew tap data-wise/tap

# 2. Install flow-cli
brew install flow-cli

That's it! Homebrew manages the installation and keeps flow-cli updated.

Benefits: - ✅ No plugin manager configuration needed - ✅ Automatic PATH setup - ✅ Easy updates: brew upgrade flow-cli - ✅ Clean uninstall: brew uninstall flow-cli

docs.title: Alternative: Quick Install Script
docs.text:
For auto-detection of your plugin manager:

curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Data-Wise/flow-cli/main/install.sh | bash

This auto-detects your plugin manager (antidote, zinit, oh-my-zsh) and installs accordingly.

docs.title: Plugin Manager Installation
docs.text:
Choose your plugin manager if not using Homebrew:

AntidoteZinitOh-My-ZshManual 
# Add to your plugins file
echo "Data-Wise/flow-cli" >> ~/.zsh_plugins.txt

# Regenerate plugins
antidote update

# Add to ~/.zshrc
zinit light Data-Wise/flow-cli

# Clone to custom plugins
git clone https://github.com/Data-Wise/flow-cli.git \
  ${ZSH_CUSTOM:-~/.oh-my-zsh/custom}/plugins/flow-cli

# Add to plugins in ~/.zshrc
plugins=(... flow-cli)

# Clone repository
git clone https://github.com/Data-Wise/flow-cli.git ~/.flow-cli

# Add to ~/.zshrc
echo 'source ~/.flow-cli/flow.plugin.zsh' >> ~/.zshrc

docs.title: Reload Shell
docs.text:
If using Homebrew: No reload needed! Commands are immediately available.

If using plugin manager or manual install:

source ~/.zshrc
# Or just restart your terminal

docs.text: TL;DR: Get up and running with Flow CLI in 5 minutes - install, start a session, log wins, finish.

# 2. Start a session

docs.title: The Core Workflow
docs.text:
Flow CLI is built around a simple, ADHD-friendly workflow:

work my-project     # 1. Start a focused session
# ... do your work ...
win "Did the thing"  # 2. Log your wins
finish "Done!"       # 3. End and optionally commit

That's it! Everything else builds on this foundation.

docs.title: Step 1: Verify Installation
docs.text:
Check that flow-cli is loaded:

# Should show version
flow --version

# Should show help
flow help

If commands aren't found, ensure the plugin is sourced in your .zshrc:

# Via antidote
antidote load data-wise/flow-cli

# Or manual source
source /path/to/flow-cli/flow.plugin.zsh

docs.title: Step 2: Start Your First Session
docs.text:
# Start working on a project
work my-project

# Or use the interactive picker
work

You'll see:

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

🟢 Status: active
🎯 Focus: Implement new feature

What happened:

  • Changed to project directory
  • Started session tracking
  • Opened your editor
  • Showed project context

docs.title: Step 3: Log Your Wins
docs.text:
As you accomplish things, log them:

win "Implemented user login"
win "Fixed that annoying bug"
win --ship "Deployed to production"

Output:

🎉 WIN LOGGED! #code
Implemented user login

Keep it up! 🚀

docs.text:
Wins are auto-categorized, or you can specify:

Flag Category Icon --code Code work 💻 --docs Documentation 📝 --fix Bug fix 🔧 --ship Deployed 🚀 --test Testing 🧪 --review Code review 👀

docs.title: "zsh functions not loading"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

dash
# zsh: command not found: dash

Cause: Shell configuration not sourced

Solution:

# Reload shell configuration
source ~/.zshrc

# Or restart terminal

Verify:

# Check functions exist
ls ~/.config/zsh/functions/adhd-helpers.zsh

# Check .zshrc sources functions
grep "adhd-helpers" ~/.zshrc

docs.title: ".zshrc not found"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

source ~/.zshrc
# No such file or directory

Cause: Flow CLI installed in ~/.config/zsh/ but .zshrc not updated

Solution:

# Create/update .zshrc
echo 'source ~/.config/zsh/.zshrc' >> ~/.zshrc

# Reload
source ~/.zshrc

docs.title: "Functions work but aliases don't"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

dash  # works
rload # zsh: command not found

Cause: Alias file not sourced

Solution:

# Check if aliases.zsh exists
ls ~/.config/zsh/aliases.zsh

# Check if sourced in .zshrc
grep "aliases.zsh" ~/.config/zsh/.zshrc

# If missing, add:
echo 'source ~/.config/zsh/aliases.zsh' >> ~/.config/zsh/.zshrc
source ~/.zshrc

docs.title: "dash: command not found"
docs.text:
Quick fix:

# Option 1: Reload shell
source ~/.zshrc

# Option 2: Check function exists
type dash

# Option 3: Manually source
source ~/.config/zsh/functions/adhd-helpers.zsh

Permanent fix:

# Ensure .zshrc sources functions
cat ~/.config/zsh/.zshrc | grep adhd-helpers

# If missing, add:
echo 'source ~/.config/zsh/functions/adhd-helpers.zsh' >> ~/.config/zsh/.zshrc

docs.title: "flow: command not found"
docs.text:
Cause: Plugin not sourced in shell

Solution:

# Check if flow function exists
type flow

# If not found, ensure plugin is sourced in .zshrc:

# Via antidote (recommended)
antidote bundle data-wise/flow-cli

# Or manual source
source /path/to/flow-cli/flow.plugin.zsh

# Reload shell
source ~/.zshrc

# Verify
type flow

docs.title: "just-start: command not found"
docs.text:
Cause: Function not defined

Solution:

# Check if function exists
type just-start

# If not found, source the file
source ~/.config/zsh/functions/adhd-helpers.zsh

# Verify
type just-start

docs.title: "Dashboard won't launch"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

dash
# Error or blank output

Solutions:

# 1. Check terminal supports required features
echo $TERM  # Should be xterm-256color or similar

# 2. Check fzf is installed (for interactive mode)
which fzf
brew install fzf  # If missing

# 3. Reload plugin
source ~/.zshrc

# 4. Try different modes
dash          # Terminal dashboard
dash -i       # Interactive (requires fzf)
dash --fast   # Quick mode

docs.title: "Dashboard shows no projects"
docs.text:
Cause: No .STATUS files found

Solution:

# Create .STATUS for existing projects
cd ~/projects/your-category/your-project
flow status your-project --create

# Verify
flow status your-project --show

# Check dashboard
dash

docs.title: "Dashboard not refreshing"
docs.text:
Symptoms: Data doesn't update after changes

Solutions:

# 1. Press 'r' to refresh in dashboard

# 2. Use watch mode for live updates
dash --watch

# 3. Check .STATUS files are being updated
cat ~/projects/category/project/.STATUS

# 4. Restart terminal and reload
source ~/.zshrc
dash

docs.title: "Project type not detected"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

cd ~/projects/your-project
work .
# Project type not detected, opening in default editor

Cause: No recognized project files

Solution:

# For R packages, ensure these exist:
ls DESCRIPTION  # R package
ls package.json # Node.js
ls Cargo.toml   # Rust
ls *.qmd        # Quarto

# Or manually specify type:
flow status . --create
# Edit .STATUS file to set type manually

docs.title: "Wrong editor opens"
docs.text:
Symptoms: VS Code opens when you want RStudio

Solution:

# Check project type detection
cd ~/projects/your-project
cat .STATUS | grep type

# For R packages:
# Ensure DESCRIPTION file exists
ls DESCRIPTION

# Edit work function if needed
# (advanced - edit ~/.config/zsh/functions/work.zsh)

docs.title: "Project not appearing in dashboard"
docs.text:
Cause: No .STATUS file or wrong location

Solution:

# Check if .STATUS exists
cd ~/projects/category/project
ls -la .STATUS

# If missing, create it:
flow status project-name --create

# Check dashboard
dash

docs.title: "Status update fails"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

flow status project active P0 "Task" 80
# Error: Cannot update status

Solutions:

# 1. Check .STATUS file permissions
cd ~/projects/category/project
ls -la .STATUS

# If not writable:
chmod 644 .STATUS

# 2. Check .STATUS format
cat .STATUS
# Should have valid fields

# 3. Try creating fresh
mv .STATUS .STATUS.bak
flow status project --create

docs.title: "Interactive mode not working"
docs.text:
Symptoms: Prompts don't appear

Solution:

# Use quick mode instead:
flow status project active P1 "Task" 50

# Or check terminal:
# Ensure not in non-interactive shell
echo $-
# Should include 'i' for interactive

docs.title: "Progress not showing in dashboard"
docs.text:
Cause: .STATUS file format issue

Solution:

# Check .STATUS format
cd ~/projects/category/project
cat .STATUS

# Should have:
# progress: 80

# If missing or malformed, recreate:
flow status project active P1 "Task" 80

docs.title: "Dashboard slow to load"
docs.text:
Symptoms: Dashboard takes >2 seconds to load

Solutions:

# 1. Use fast mode
dash --fast

# 2. Filter to specific category
dash teaching
dash active

# 3. Check number of projects
ls -d ~/projects/*/* | wc -l
# If >50 projects, consider archiving old ones

# 4. Use targeted commands
dash active    # Only active projects

docs.title: "Commands feel laggy"
docs.text:
Symptoms: dash or status takes >2 seconds

Solutions:

# 1. Check filesystem speed
time ls ~/projects/*/*/.STATUS

# 2. Reduce project count
# Move completed/archived projects

# 3. Check disk space
df -h ~

# 4. Check for file sync conflicts
# (Dropbox, Google Drive, iCloud)

docs.title: "High CPU usage"
docs.text:
Symptoms: Shell processes consuming high CPU

Solutions:

# 1. Use fast mode for quick checks
dash --fast

# 2. Avoid watch mode unless needed
# dash --watch runs continuously

# 3. Check for runaway processes
ps aux | grep zsh

docs.title: "Git aliases not working"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

gst
# zsh: command not found: gst

Cause: OMZ git plugin not loaded

Solution:

# Check if plugin loaded
omz plugin list | grep git

# If not loaded, add to .zshrc:
# plugins=(git other-plugins)

# Or source manually:
source $ZSH/plugins/git/git.plugin.zsh

docs.title: "gcmsg doesn't work"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

gcmsg "message"
# zsh: command not found: gcmsg

Solution:

# Ensure git plugin loaded
grep "plugins=.*git" ~/.zshrc

# If missing, use full command:
git commit -m "message"

# Or add plugin:
# Edit ~/.zshrc, add 'git' to plugins array

docs.title: "Permissions denied"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

flow status project active P0 "Task" 80
# Error: Permission denied

Solution:

# Check file permissions
cd ~/projects/category/project
ls -la .STATUS

# Fix permissions:
chmod 644 .STATUS

# Fix directory:
chmod 755 .

docs.title: "Encoding issues (weird characters)"
docs.text:
Symptoms: Dashboard shows � or other strange characters

Solution:

# Set UTF-8 encoding
export LANG=en_US.UTF-8
export LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8

# Add to .zshrc for permanence:
echo 'export LANG=en_US.UTF-8' >> ~/.zshrc
echo 'export LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8' >> ~/.zshrc

docs.title: "Time zone issues"
docs.text:
Symptoms: Timestamps wrong in dashboard

Solution:

# Check system timezone
date

# Set timezone (example: US Eastern)
export TZ='America/New_York'

# Add to .zshrc:
echo 'export TZ="America/New_York"' >> ~/.zshrc

docs.title: Check Logs
docs.text:
# Enable debug mode
export FLOW_DEBUG=1
source ~/.zshrc

# Run command with debug output
dash 2>&1 | tee debug.log

# Check for shell errors
zsh -x -c 'source flow.plugin.zsh' 2>&1 | head -50

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
# Run health check
flow doctor

# Check all components
type flow work dash pick
type cc g mcp r qu

# Check plugin is sourced
grep -r "flow-cli" ~/.zshrc ~/.config/zsh/

docs.title: Reset to Defaults
docs.text:
# Backup current config
cp ~/.config/zsh/.zshrc ~/.config/zsh/.zshrc.backup

# Re-source clean config
source ~/.config/zsh/.zshrc

# If still broken, re-source the plugin:
source /path/to/flow-cli/flow.plugin.zsh

# Or reinstall via antidote:
antidote update data-wise/flow-cli

docs.title: Report Issues
docs.text:
If you can't solve the issue:

  1. Check existing docs:
  2. Quick Start
  3. Installation

  4. Tutorial 1

  5. Gather debug info:

# System info
echo "OS: $(uname -a)"
echo "Shell: $SHELL"
echo "ZSH: $ZSH_VERSION"

# Flow CLI info
flow doctor
type flow
ls -la ~/.config/zsh/functions/
  1. Create issue file:
# Create detailed bug report
cat > ~/FLOW-CLI-ISSUE.md <<EOF
## Issue Description
[Describe what's wrong]

## Steps to Reproduce
1. Command I ran: ...
2. What happened: ...
3. What I expected: ...

## Environment
OS: $(uname -a)
Shell: $SHELL
ZSH Version: $ZSH_VERSION

## Error Output
[Paste error messages]

## What I've Tried
- Tried X: didn't work
- Tried Y: same error
EOF

docs.title: Configuration Management Workflow
docs.text: Quick Answer: flow config manages all flow-cli settings. View, edit, save, and manage configuration profiles for different workflows.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
flow-cli configuration controls behavior across all commands, from colors to ADHD features to timer defaults.

What you can configure: - Core settings (projects root, Atlas integration) - UI preferences (colors, icons, progress bars) - Timer defaults (focus time, breaks) - ADHD features (auto-breadcrumb, dopamine mode) - Git behavior (auto-commit, push settings) - AI integration (provider, context, verbosity)

docs.title: View All Settings
docs.text:
# Show all configuration
flow config show

# Filter by keyword
flow config show timer
flow config show adhd

Output example: 

╔════════════════════════════════════════════╗
║ FLOW-CLI CONFIGURATION                     ║
╚════════════════════════════════════════════╝

Core Settings:
  projects_root       /Users/dt/projects
  atlas_enabled       auto
  quiet               no
  debug               no

Timer Settings:
  timer_default       25
  timer_break         5
  timer_long_break    15
  timer_sound         yes

ADHD Features:
  auto_breadcrumb     yes
  dopamine_mode       yes
  session_timeout     3600

docs.title: Get/Set Individual Values
docs.text:
# Get current value
flow config get timer_default
# → 25

# Set new value
flow config set timer_default 30
# ✓ timer_default: 25 → 30

# Shorthand (key=value)
flow config timer_default=30

docs.title: Edit Configuration File
docs.text:
# Open config in editor
flow config edit

# Default editor: $EDITOR (vim/nano/etc)

After editing: 

# Reload configuration?
# [y/N]: y
# ✓ Configuration reloaded

docs.title: Built-in Profiles
docs.text:
flow-cli includes 4 optimized profiles:

Profile Best For Features minimal Quiet workflows Minimal output, essential features only developer Full dev work All features, verbose output adhd Maximum support Dopamine mode, auto-breadcrumb, timers researcher Academic work Long timers, quiet mode, export features

docs.title: Using Profiles
docs.text:
# List available profiles
flow config profile list

# Load a profile
flow config profile load adhd
flow config profile adhd      # Shorthand

# Save current config as custom profile
flow config profile save my-workflow

Example output: 

Built-in Profiles:
  minimal     Quiet mode, minimal features
  developer   Full dev features
  adhd        Maximum ADHD support
  researcher  Academic workflow

Custom Profiles:
  my-workflow (saved 2026-01-10)

docs.title: Workflow 1: First-Time Setup
docs.text:
# Run interactive wizard
flow config wizard

# Or use profile as starting point
flow config profile load adhd

# Customize specific settings
flow config set timer_default 30
flow config set projects_root ~/work

# Save configuration
flow config save

docs.title: Workflow 2: Project-Specific Config
docs.text:
Different config for work vs personal projects:

Work profile: 

# Create work profile
flow config profile load minimal
flow config set quiet yes
flow config set auto_commit yes
flow config set push_after_finish yes
flow config profile save work

Personal profile: 

# Create personal profile
flow config profile load adhd
flow config set dopamine_mode yes
flow config set timer_default 25
flow config profile save personal

Switch based on context: 

# In work project
cd ~/work/client-project
flow config profile work

# In personal project
cd ~/projects/hobby-app
flow config profile personal

docs.title: Workflow 3: Team Standardization
docs.text:
Share config across team:

# Export team config
flow config export > team-flow-config.sh

# Team members import
source team-flow-config.sh
flow config save

Example export: 

# Generated by flow config export
export FLOW_CONFIG_projects_root="$HOME/workspace"
export FLOW_CONFIG_atlas_enabled="yes"
export FLOW_CONFIG_auto_commit="yes"
export FLOW_CONFIG_timer_default="25"

docs.title: Workflow 4: Temporary Override
docs.text:
Override config for single session:

# Set for current shell only (doesn't persist)
export FLOW_QUIET=1
export FLOW_DEBUG=1

# Run commands
flow work my-project
flow test

# Exit shell - config reverts to saved
exit

docs.title: Config File Location
docs.text:
Default: ~/.config/flow-cli/config.sh

Custom location: 

export FLOW_CONFIG_FILE="$HOME/.flow/my-config.sh"

docs.title: Config File Format
docs.text:
# ~/.config/flow-cli/config.sh
# Auto-generated by flow config save

# Core
FLOW_CONFIG[projects_root]="$HOME/projects"
FLOW_CONFIG[atlas_enabled]="auto"
FLOW_CONFIG[quiet]="no"

# Timer
FLOW_CONFIG[timer_default]="25"
FLOW_CONFIG[timer_break]="5"

# ADHD
FLOW_CONFIG[dopamine_mode]="yes"
FLOW_CONFIG[auto_breadcrumb]="yes"

# Git
FLOW_CONFIG[auto_commit]="no"
FLOW_CONFIG[push_after_finish]="ask"

docs.title: Programmatic Access (ZSH)
docs.text:
# Read config value in your scripts
local timer=$(_flow_config_get "timer_default")
echo "Timer: $timer minutes"

# Set config value
_flow_config_set "timer_default" "30"

# Reset to default
_flow_config_reset "timer_default"

docs.title: Reset Configuration
docs.text:
# Reset single key to default
flow config reset timer_default

# Reset all to defaults (with confirmation)
flow config reset --all

# Force reset without confirmation
flow config reset --all -f

docs.title: Backup Configuration
docs.text:
# Manual backup
cp ~/.config/flow-cli/config.sh \
   ~/.config/flow-cli/config.sh.backup

# Restore from backup
cp ~/.config/flow-cli/config.sh.backup \
   ~/.config/flow-cli/config.sh
flow config reload

docs.title: Version Control
docs.text:
Track config in git:

cd ~/.config/flow-cli
git init
git add config.sh
git commit -m "Initial flow-cli config"

# Update config
flow config set timer_default 30
flow config save
git commit -am "Update timer default"

# Restore old version
git checkout HEAD~1 config.sh
flow config reload

docs.title: Issue: Changes not taking effect
docs.text:
Symptoms: Settings don't change behavior

Cause: Config not saved or not reloaded

Solution: 

# Save changes
flow config save

# Reload shell
exec zsh

# Or reload without restarting
flow config reload

docs.title: Issue: Config file not found
docs.text:
Symptoms: No config file found, using defaults

Cause: Config file not created yet

Solution: 

# Create config file
flow config save

# Verify location
flow config path

docs.title: Issue: Invalid config value
docs.text:
Symptoms: Invalid value. Use: yes/no

Cause: Wrong value format for key

Solution: 

# Check allowed values
flow config set timer_default
# → Shows current value and hints

# Use correct format
# Boolean: yes/no (not 1/0 or true/false)
# Number: integers only
# Enum: specified values only

docs.title: Issue: Profile not found
docs.text:
Symptoms: Profile not found: my-profile

Cause: Typo or profile not saved

Solution: 

# List available profiles
flow config profile list

# Save profile if needed
flow config profile save my-profile

docs.title: DO ✅
docs.text:
1. Save config after changes 

flow config set timer_default 30
flow config save  # Don't forget!

2. Use profiles for different contexts 

flow config profile save work
flow config profile save personal
flow config profile save client-project

3. Document custom settings 

# Add comments to config file
vim ~/.config/flow-cli/config.sh

# Custom timer for deep work
FLOW_CONFIG[timer_default]="45"  # 45min focus blocks

4. Test changes before saving 

# Try temporary override
FLOW_QUIET=1 flow dash

# If good, make permanent
flow config set quiet yes
flow config save

docs.title: DON'T ❌
docs.text:
1. Don't edit config while flow commands running 

# ❌ Bad: Edit during work session
flow work my-project  # Session running
# ... in another terminal: flow config edit

# ✅ Good: Edit before/after
finish
flow config edit

2. Don't use environment variables for permanent config 

# ❌ Bad: In .zshrc (overrides config file)
export FLOW_QUIET=1

# ✅ Good: Use config system
flow config set quiet yes
flow config save

3. Don't forget to reload 

# ❌ Bad: Expect instant changes
flow config set timer_default 30
# Commands still use old value

# ✅ Good: Reload
flow config save
exec zsh

docs.title: From v3.x to v4.x
docs.text:
# Old format (environment variables)
export FLOW_PROJECTS_ROOT="$HOME/projects"
export FLOW_TIMER_DEFAULT="25"

# New format (config system)
flow config set projects_root "$HOME/projects"
flow config set timer_default 25
flow config save

docs.title: Import Old Config
docs.text:
# If you have old env vars in .zshrc, migrate:
OLD_ROOT="$FLOW_PROJECTS_ROOT"
OLD_TIMER="$FLOW_TIMER_DEFAULT"

flow config set projects_root "$OLD_ROOT"
flow config set timer_default "$OLD_TIMER"
flow config save

# Remove old vars from .zshrc
vim ~/.zshrc
# Delete: export FLOW_* lines

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Key Points:

  1. ✅ flow config show - View all settings
  2. ✅ flow config set key value - Change settings
  3. ✅ flow config save - Persist changes
  4. ✅ flow config profile load - Quick preset switching
  5. ✅ flow config wizard - Interactive first-time setup

Quick workflow:

# View current
flow config show

# Make changes
flow config set timer_default 30
flow config set dopamine_mode yes

# Save and reload
flow config save
exec zsh

# Or use profile
flow config profile load adhd

docs.title: Dopamine Features Guide
docs.text:
Motivation-boosting features for sustained productivity

Last Updated: 2025-12-26 Version: v3.5.0 Target Audience: All users wanting to stay motivated

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Flow CLI v3.5.0 introduces dopamine features - small, visible rewards that reinforce good work habits. These features are designed with ADHD users in mind but benefit everyone.

Key Concepts:

Feature Purpose Command Win Tracking Celebrate accomplishments win, yay Streak Counter Build momentum dash Daily Goals Progress visibility flow goal Categories Organized wins Auto-detected

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Log a win
win "Fixed the login bug"

# See your wins
yay

# Check your streak
dash

# Set a daily goal
flow goal set 3

docs.title: Logging Wins
docs.text:
The win command logs accomplishments with automatic categorization:

# Basic usage
win "Implemented user authentication"

# With explicit category
win --category ship "Deployed v3.5.0 to production"

# Short form
win "Fixed bug #123"

docs.title: Win Categories
docs.text:
Wins are automatically categorized based on keywords:

Category Icon Trigger Words code 💻 implement, add, create, build, refactor docs 📝 doc, readme, guide, tutorial, comment review 👀 review, pr, feedback, approve ship 🚀 deploy, release, ship, publish, merge fix 🔧 fix, bug, issue, resolve, patch test 🧪 test, spec, coverage, passing other ✨ (default)

docs.title: Viewing Wins
docs.text:
# Recent wins (default: last 5)
yay

# Weekly summary with activity graph
yay --week

# All wins from today
yay --today

# Wins by category
yay --category code

Example Output:

🎉 Recent Wins
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

Total: 3 wins | Streak: 🔥 5 days

docs.title: Streak Counter
docs.text: Streaks track consecutive days with at least one work session.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Start a session → Counts toward today's streak
  2. Work consecutive days → Streak increases
  3. Miss a day → Streak resets to 0

docs.title: Viewing Your Streak
docs.text:
The streak appears in:

  • Dashboard header: 🔥 5 day streak
  • Win display: Shows at bottom of yay
  • Status output: Part of extended status
# Quick streak check
dash

# Detailed view
status --extended

docs.title: Streak Benefits
docs.text: Streak Visual Meaning 0-2 🌱 Building momentum 3-6 🔥 On a roll 7-13 🔥🔥 Strong week 14+ 🔥🔥🔥 Exceptional streak

docs.title: Daily Goals
docs.text: Set a target number of wins per day to stay motivated.

docs.title: Setting Goals
docs.text:
# Set global daily goal (applies to all projects)
flow goal set 3

# Set per-project goal (overrides global)
flow goal set 5 --project flow-cli

# View current goal and progress
flow goal

docs.title: Goal Progress
docs.text:
The goal appears in the dashboard wins section:

🎯 Daily Goal: ██████░░░░ 2/3 wins

docs.title: Per-Project Goals
docs.text:
Add to your project's .STATUS file:

## daily_goal: 5

This overrides the global goal when working in that project.

Priority Order:

  1. Project .STATUS → daily_goal field
  2. Global ~/.local/share/flow/goal.json
  3. Default: 3 wins

docs.title: Extended .STATUS Format
docs.text:
v3.5.0 adds new fields to the .STATUS file format:

## Project: my-project

## Type: node

## Status: active

## Phase: Development

## Priority: 1

## Progress: 45

## daily_goal: 3

## wins: Deployed v1.0 (2025-12-26)

## streak: 5

## last_active: 2025-12-26 14:30

## tags: typescript, api, backend

docs.title: New Fields
docs.text: Field Type Description daily_goal number Per-project win goal wins text Last win recorded streak number Current streak last_active datetime Last activity tags comma-sep Project tags for filtering

docs.title: Viewing Extended Status
docs.text:
# Show all extended fields
status --extended

# Or short form
status -e

docs.title: Dashboard Integration

All dopamine features appear in the dashboard:

docs.text:
The dashboard TUI (Terminal UI) now has keyboard shortcuts:

dash -i
# or
dash --interactive

docs.text: Key Action Enter Open project Ctrl-E Edit .STATUS file Ctrl-S Show status Ctrl-W Log a win ? Show help Esc Exit

docs.text:
Auto-refresh the dashboard:

docs.title: 1. Log Wins Immediately
docs.text:
Don't wait - log wins as soon as you complete something:

# After fixing a bug

docs.title: 2. Keep Goals Achievable
docs.text:
Start with a modest goal and increase:

# Start small

Make dash part of your morning routine:

# Morning check

morning

Let the system categorize, but override when needed:

docs.title: Dotfile Management Workflow
docs.text: Level: Beginner to Intermediate Time: 15 minutes Goal: Master dotfile management with chezmoi and the DOT dispatcher

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Check status
dot

# Edit a dotfile (must be tracked first)
dot edit .zshrc

# Pull updates from remote
dot sync

# Push your changes
dot push

docs.title: Required: Chezmoi
docs.text:
# Install
brew install chezmoi

# Initialize (creates ~/.local/share/chezmoi/)
chezmoi init

# Track your first file
chezmoi add ~/.zshrc

docs.title: Optional: Bitwarden (for secrets)
docs.text:
brew install bitwarden-cli
bw login

docs.title: Workflow 1: Quick Edit
docs.text: Edit a dotfile with preview and apply workflow.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
# 1. Edit (opens $EDITOR with source file)
dot edit .zshrc

Output: 

ℹ Opening in vim: dot_zshrc

[Make changes, save, exit editor]

✓ Changes detected!
───────────────────────────────────────────
@@ -5,0 +6 @@
+export NEW_VAR="test"
───────────────────────────────────────────

ℹ Apply changes?
  y - Apply now
  d - Show detailed diff
  n - Keep in staging

Apply? [Y/n/d]

Options:

Key Action y Apply changes to ~/.zshrc now d Show full diff, then prompt again n Keep in chezmoi source (apply later with dot apply)

docs.title: Apply Later
docs.text:
If you pressed 'n', changes are in chezmoi but not yet in your home directory:

# See pending changes
dot diff

# Apply all pending
dot apply

# Preview first
dot apply --dry-run

docs.title: Workflow 2: Dry-Run Preview
docs.text:
Preview changes without applying them.

dot apply --dry-run
# or
dot apply -n

Output (no changes): 

ℹ DRY-RUN MODE - No changes will be applied

✓ No pending changes

Output (with changes): 

ℹ DRY-RUN MODE - No changes will be applied

ℹ Showing what would change (dry-run)...
[chezmoi verbose diff]

✓ Dry-run complete - no changes applied

docs.title: When to Use
docs.text:
• After dot sync to see incoming changes
  • Before applying templates with secrets
  • To verify changes are correct

docs.title: First Machine Setup
docs.text:
# Initialize with remote
chezmoi init https://github.com/user/dotfiles.git

# Add files
chezmoi add ~/.zshrc
chezmoi add ~/.gitconfig
chezmoi add ~/.tmux.conf

# Push to remote
dot push

docs.title: On Other Machines
docs.text:
# Clone and initialize
chezmoi init https://github.com/user/dotfiles.git

# Apply dotfiles
dot apply

docs.title: Daily Sync
docs.text:
# Pull from remote
dot sync

# Output if updates exist:
# ℹ Fetching from remote...
# ℹ Remote has updates:
# abc1234 Add new alias
# Apply updates? [Y/n/d]

# Push local changes
dot push

docs.title: Setup Bitwarden
docs.text:
# Install CLI
brew install bitwarden-cli

# Login (first time)
bw login

# Unlock vault (each shell session)
dot unlock

docs.title: Store Secrets
docs.text:
1. Open Bitwarden app or web vault
  2. Create Login item with name like github-token
  3. Put secret in password field
  4. Save

docs.title: Retrieve Secrets
docs.text:
# List available secrets
dot secret list

# Output:
# ℹ Retrieving items from vault...
# 🔑 github-token (Work/GitHub)
# 🔑 anthropic-api-key (AI/Keys)

# Retrieve (no echo)
TOKEN=$(dot secret github-token)

docs.title: Use in Templates
docs.text:
Create template: ~/.local/share/chezmoi/dot_zshrc.tmpl

# Regular content
export PATH=$HOME/bin:$PATH

# Secrets from Bitwarden
export GITHUB_TOKEN="{{ bitwarden "item" "github-token" }}"

Apply with secrets: 

dot unlock
dot apply --dry-run  # Preview
dot apply            # Apply

docs.title: Create Tokens with Wizards

# NPM automation token
dot token npm

dot secrets sync github

Output:

Select secrets to sync:
  [x] GITHUB_TOKEN
  [x] NPM_TOKEN

💡 Run 'direnv allow' to activate

docs.title: Quick Config Change
docs.text: dot edit .gitconfig  # Edit, apply immediately

docs.title: Safe Batch Changes
docs.text:
dot edit .zshrc      # Press 'n' to defer
dot edit .gitconfig  # Press 'n' to defer
dot diff             # Review all
dot apply --dry-run  # Preview
dot apply            # Apply all

docs.title: Emergency Rollback
docs.text:
# Restore from chezmoi source
chezmoi apply --force

# Or revert chezmoi source to remote
cd ~/.local/share/chezmoi
git checkout -- .
dot apply

docs.title: File Not Tracked
docs.text:
✗ File not found in managed dotfiles: .zshrc
ℹ Use 'chezmoi add <file>' to start tracking a new file

Fix: chezmoi add ~/.zshrc

docs.title: Vault Locked
docs.text:
✗ Bitwarden vault is locked
ℹ Run: dot unlock

Fix: dot unlock

docs.title: Session Expired
docs.text:
✗ Session expired
Run: dot unlock

Fix: dot unlock (re-enter master password)

docs.title: Command Reference
docs.text: Command Description dot Show status dot edit <file> Edit with preview dot diff Show pending changes dot apply Apply pending changes dot apply -n Dry-run preview dot sync Pull from remote dot push Push to remote dot unlock Unlock Bitwarden (15-min session) dot secret <name> Retrieve secret dot secret list List secrets dot secrets Dashboard with expiration dot token github GitHub PAT wizard dot token npm NPM token wizard dot token pypi PyPI token wizard dot token <n> --refresh Rotate existing token dot secrets sync github Sync to GitHub Actions dot env init Generate .envrc dot doctor Run diagnostics dot help Show help

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Track files first - chezmoi add before dot edit
  2. Use dry-run - Preview before applying templates
  3. Small commits - One logical change per dot push
  4. Lock vault - bw lock when done with secrets
  5. Check status - Run dot to see current state

docs.title: Dotfile Management Guide
docs.text:
Manage your dotfiles across machines with chezmoi and Bitwarden secrets

Last Updated: 2026-01-11 Version: v2.0.0 Target Audience: Users wanting to synchronize dotfiles and manage secrets securely

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The dot dispatcher provides a unified interface for managing your dotfiles with chezmoi and secrets with Bitwarden CLI. It's designed to be ADHD-friendly with smart defaults, clear status displays, and progressive disclosure of complexity.

Key Benefits:

Feature Benefit Sync dotfiles Keep configs consistent across machines Secure secrets Store API keys/tokens in Bitwarden Safe edits Preview changes before applying Fast operations < 500ms for most commands Optional tools Works even if tools not installed

docs.title: 1. Install Tools
docs.text:
# Required for dotfile sync
brew install chezmoi

# Required for secret management
brew install bitwarden-cli

# Optional (for pretty secret listings)
brew install jq

docs.title: 2. Initialize Chezmoi
docs.text:
# Option A: Start fresh
chezmoi init

# Option B: Clone existing dotfiles
chezmoi init https://github.com/yourusername/dotfiles

docs.title: 3. Authenticate Bitwarden
docs.text:
# One-time login
bw login

docs.title: 4. Start Using
docs.text:
# Check status
dot

# Edit a dotfile
dot edit .zshrc

# Unlock secrets
dot unlock

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text:
flowchart TD
    A[User] --> B{dot command}

    B -->|dot status| C[Show Status]
    B -->|dot edit| D[Edit Workflow]
    B -->|dot sync| E[Sync Workflow]
    B -->|dot unlock| F[Unlock Bitwarden]
    B -->|dot secret| G[Retrieve Secret]

    D --> D1[Open in $EDITOR]
    D1 --> D2{Modified?}
    D2 -->|Yes| D3[Show Diff]
    D3 --> D4{Apply?}
    D4 -->|Yes| D5[chezmoi apply]
    D2 -->|No| D6[No changes]

    E --> E1[git fetch]
    E1 --> E2{Behind?}
    E2 -->|Yes| E3[Show commits]
    E3 --> E4{Pull?}
    E4 -->|Yes| E5[chezmoi update]
    E2 -->|No| E6[Up to date]

    F --> F1[Prompt password]
    F1 --> F2[bw unlock --raw]
    F2 --> F3[Export BW_SESSION]
    F3 --> F4[Validate session]

    G --> G1{Session valid?}
    G1 -->|Yes| G2[bw get password]
    G1 -->|No| G3[Error: vault locked]
    G2 --> G4[Return value no echo]

    C --> C1[chezmoi status]
    C1 --> C2[Check git status]
    C2 --> C3[Format display]

    style D5 fill:#90EE90
    style E5 fill:#90EE90
    style F4 fill:#90EE90
    style G4 fill:#90EE90
    style D6 fill:#FFD700
    style E6 fill:#FFD700
    style G3 fill:#FF6B6B

Key Components:

  • Chezmoi: Dotfile source control & templating
  • Bitwarden CLI: Secret management
  • Git: Version control & sync
  • Flow-CLI: Unified interface

docs.title: Workflow 1: Edit Dotfile (Most Common)
docs.text:
# 1. Check current status
dot

# 2. Edit a file
dot edit .zshrc

# 3. Preview changes (automatic)
# Shows: Modified: ~/.zshrc

# 4. Apply changes
# Prompt: Apply changes? [Y/n/d(iff)]
# Press: y

# 5. Changes applied to home directory

Time: < 30 seconds Commands: 2 (dot, dot edit .zshrc)

docs.title: Workflow 2: Sync from Another Machine
docs.text:
# 1. Pull latest changes
dot sync

# 2. Review what changed
# Shows: Remote has updates: [commit list]

# 3. Confirm pull
# Prompt: Pull updates? [Y/n]
# Press: y

# 4. Apply changes (if needed)
dot apply

Time: 10-30 seconds Commands: 2 (dot sync, dot apply)

docs.title: Workflow 3: Push Local Changes
docs.text:
# 1. Check what's modified
dot diff

# 2. Push changes
dot push

# 3. Enter commit message
# Prompt: Commit message:
# Type: "Update ZSH aliases"

# 4. Committed and pushed

Time: 20-40 seconds Commands: 2-3 (dot diff, dot push)

docs.title: Workflow 4: Use Secret in Template
docs.text:
# 1. Unlock Bitwarden
dot unlock

# 2. Edit template file
dot edit .gitconfig

# 3. Add secret reference in template
# {{ bitwarden "item" "github-token" }}

# 4. Apply template (automatic)
# Result: ~/.gitconfig contains actual token

Time: 1-2 minutes Commands: 2-3 (dot unlock, dot edit)

docs.title: Directory Structure
docs.text:
~/.local/share/chezmoi/          # Source files (templates)
├── .git/                        # Git repository
├── dot_zshrc.tmpl               # Template → ~/.zshrc
├── dot_gitconfig.tmpl           # Template → ~/.gitconfig
├── private_env.sh.tmpl          # Private → ~/.env.sh
└── ...

~/                               # Applied files
├── .zshrc                       # Generated from template
├── .gitconfig                   # Generated from template
└── ...

docs.title: Naming Convention
docs.text:
Chezmoi uses special prefixes for file transformations:

Prefix Result Example dot_ Adds leading . dot_zshrc → .zshrc .tmpl Template processing dot_gitconfig.tmpl → .gitconfig private_ Executable only by you private_env.sh → .env.sh (0600) executable_ Executable file executable_script.sh → script.sh (0755)

docs.title: Adding New Files
docs.text:
# Add file to chezmoi (starts tracking)
chezmoi add ~/.zshrc

# Add as template (for variable substitution)
chezmoi add --template ~/.gitconfig

docs.title: Removing Files
docs.text:
# Stop tracking a file
chezmoi forget ~/.old_config

# Remove from chezmoi directory
rm ~/.local/share/chezmoi/dot_old_config

docs.title: Initial Configuration
docs.text:
# 1. Login (one-time)
bw login

# 2. Test authentication
bw status
# Output: {"status":"locked",...}

# 3. Unlock vault (per-session)
dot unlock

# 4. Verify unlock
dot secret list

docs.title: Creating Items
docs.text:
# Option A: Via CLI
bw create item \
  --name "github-token" \
  --username "youruser" \
  --password "ghp_..." \
  --folder "Work/GitHub"

# Option B: Via web vault
# 1. Go to vault.bitwarden.com
# 2. Add item → Login
# 3. Name: github-token
# 4. Password: ghp_...
# 5. Save

docs.title: Organizing Items
docs.text:
Use folders for organization:

Work/
├── GitHub

docs.text: Type Icon Use Case Example Login 🔑 API tokens, passwords GitHub token Secure Note 📝 SSH keys, certificates Private key Card 💳 Stripe test keys Payment API

docs.title: Token Wizards
docs.text:
Create tokens with guided wizards that handle validation and storage:

# GitHub Personal Access Token
dot token github

# NPM automation token
dot token npm

# PyPI project token
dot token pypi

Example wizard session:

🧙 GitHub Token Wizard

Select token type:

ℹ Opening GitHub token creation page...

docs.title: Session Token in History
docs.text:
Concern: - Worried about BW_SESSION in shell history

Solution:

The dot unlock command safely captures tokens without exposing them. History exclusion patterns prevent storage:

# Verify history settings
echo $HISTIGNORE

# Should include: *bw unlock*:*bw get*:*BW_SESSION*

This is automatically configured when dotfile helpers load.

docs.title: ✅ DO
docs.text:
• Unlock per-session: Run dot unlock in each shell where you need secrets
  • Lock when done: Run bw lock after template operations
  • Use templates: Store templates in chezmoi, not plain files with secrets
  • Capture securely: Use VAR=$(dot secret name) to capture without echo
  • Validate items: Use dot secret list to verify item names before using
  • Review templates: Check templates before applying to ensure no leaks

docs.title: ❌ DON'T
docs.text:
• Don't export globally: Never add export BW_SESSION=... to .zshrc
  • Don't commit secrets: Never commit files with actual secret values
  • Don't echo secrets: Avoid echo $(dot secret name) in scripts
  • Don't log secrets: Ensure secrets aren't written to logs/history
  • Don't share sessions: Each user should unlock their own vault
  • Don't hardcode tokens: Use templates and Bitwarden instead

docs.title: Security Checklist
docs.text:
# 1. Check for global BW_SESSION exports (should find nothing)
grep -r "export BW_SESSION" ~/.config/zsh ~/.zshrc ~/.zshenv 2>/dev/null

# 2. Verify history exclusion
echo $HISTIGNORE | grep "bw unlock"

# 3. Check for committed secrets (in chezmoi repo)
cd ~/.local/share/chezmoi
git log -p | grep -i "token\|password\|secret" | grep -v "bitwarden"

# 4. Audit applied files (should contain actual secrets, not templates)
grep "bitwarden" ~/.gitconfig ~/.zshrc 2>/dev/null
# Should return nothing (templates are processed)

docs.title: Monorepo Commands - ADHD-Friendly Beginner's Tutorial
docs.text:
For: Complete beginners to monorepos and npm workspaces Time to read: 10 minutes Hands-on practice: 5 minutes

UPDATE 2025-12-20: This project now uses a single CLI workspace. References to the app workspace have been kept for educational purposes, showing how multi-workspace projects work. The CLI-focused commands (npm run dev, npm run test) still apply.

docs.title: 🎯 What You'll Learn
docs.text:
By the end of this tutorial, you'll understand: 1. What a monorepo is (in simple terms) 2. How to run commands in this project 3. What each command does and when to use it

No prior experience needed!

docs.title: 📦 Part 1: What is a Monorepo? (2 min read)
The Simple Explanation
docs.text:
Think of your project like a house:

Regular project (single repo): 

🏠 One house = One project

Monorepo (this project): 

🏘️ One neighborhood = Multiple projects living together
   ├── 🏠 App house (desktop application)
   └── 🏠 CLI house (command-line tools)

docs.title: Why Does This Matter?
docs.text:
Your project has two separate but related parts:

  1. App (app/ folder) - Desktop application (Electron)
  2. CLI (cli/ folder) - Command-line integration layer

They live in the same repository (the "neighborhood") and can share things, but they're separate projects.

docs.title: 🎮 Part 2: The Basic Pattern (1 min read)
docs.text:
All commands follow this simple pattern:

npm run [action]:[workspace]

Breaking it down: - npm run - "Hey npm, run a command" - [action] - What to do (dev, test, build) - :[workspace] - Where to do it (app, cli, or both)

Example: 

npm run test:cli
     ↑     ↑    ↑
    npm   test  cli
  (tool) (what) (where)

Translation: "Use npm to test the CLI workspace"

docs.title: 🚀 Part 3: Commands You'll Actually Use (5 min read)
Command: npm run dev
docs.text:
What it does: Runs the desktop app in development mode When to use: When you want to test the app with live reload Where it runs: App workspace only

npm run dev

Example output: 

> Starting Electron app...
> App running on http://localhost:3000

docs.title: Command: npm run dev:app
docs.text:
What it does: Same as npm run dev (explicitly says "app") When to use: When you want to be clear you're running the app Where it runs: App workspace

npm run dev:app

Why two commands? - dev = shortcut (most people want the app) - dev:app = explicit (when you want to be clear)

docs.title: Command: npm run dev:cli
docs.text:
What it does: Runs CLI tests (CLI doesn't have a "dev mode") When to use: When developing/testing CLI features Where it runs: CLI workspace

npm run dev:cli

Example output: 

═══════════════════════════════════════════════
  ZSH Workflow CLI - Status Tests
═══════════════════════════════════════════════
✅ All status tests passed!

docs.title: Command: npm test
docs.text:
What it does: Tests EVERYTHING (both app and CLI) When to use: Before committing code, to make sure nothing broke Where it runs: All workspaces

npm test

What happens: 1. Tests the app (using Jest) 2. Tests the CLI (using custom tests) 3. Shows results for both

docs.title: Command: npm run test:app
docs.text:
What it does: Tests only the app When to use: When you changed app code and want quick feedback Where it runs: App workspace only

npm run test:app

docs.title: Command: npm run test:cli
docs.text:
What it does: Tests only the CLI When to use: When you changed CLI code and want quick feedback Where it runs: CLI workspace only

npm run test:cli

Example output: 

🧪 Testing Status Adapter...
Test 1: Get Current Session ✅
Test 2: Get Project Status ✅

docs.title: Command: npm run build
docs.text:
What it does: Builds the app for production When to use: When you want to create a distributable version Where it runs: App workspace only

npm run build

What happens: - Takes your source code - Packages it into a desktop app (.dmg for Mac) - Puts result in app/dist/

docs.title: Command: npm run build:app
docs.text:
What it does: Same as npm run build (explicit) When to use: When you want to be clear you're building the app

npm run build:app

docs.title: Command: npm run build:all
docs.text:
What it does: Builds all workspaces that need building When to use: Before releasing, to build everything Where it runs: Currently just app (CLI doesn't need building)

npm run build:all

Note: Right now this only builds the app, but in the future if you add more workspaces, this will build them all.

docs.title: Command: npm run clean
docs.text:
What it does: Deletes all installed dependencies and build files When to use: When things are broken and you want a fresh start What it removes: - app/node_modules/ - cli/node_modules/ - node_modules/ (root) - app/dist/ (build output)

npm run clean

⚠️ Warning: This deletes files! You'll need to run npm install after.

docs.title: Command: npm run reset
docs.text:
What it does: Cleans everything AND reinstalls dependencies When to use: "Turn it off and on again" for npm projects Steps it runs: 1. Deletes all node_modules/ and build files 2. Runs npm install to reinstall everything fresh

npm run reset

Use this when: - Weird errors you can't explain - Dependencies seem corrupted - You want a completely fresh start

docs.title: 🧠 Part 4: Decision Tree (Quick Reference)
docs.text:
What do you want to do?

├─ 🚀 Run the app
│  └─ npm run dev
│
├─ 🧪 Test my changes
│  ├─ Changed app code? → npm run test:app
│  ├─ Changed CLI code? → npm run test:cli
│  └─ Want to test everything? → npm test
│
├─ 📦 Build for distribution
│  └─ npm run build
│
└─ 🔧 Fix weird errors
   └─ npm run reset

docs.title: Scenario 1: First Time Setup
docs.text:
Goal: Get the project running for the first time

# Step 1: Install all dependencies
npm install

# Step 2: Test that everything works
npm test

# Step 3: Run the app
npm run dev

Time: 2-5 minutes (depending on internet speed)

docs.title: Scenario 2: Daily Development
docs.text:
Goal: Work on the app, make changes, test them

# Step 1: Start development mode
npm run dev

# (Make your code changes)

# Step 2: Test your changes
npm run test:app

# Step 3: If all good, you're done!

docs.title: Scenario 3: Working on CLI Features
docs.text:
Goal: Add or fix CLI functionality

# Step 1: Run CLI tests to see current state
npm run dev:cli

# (Make your code changes in cli/ folder)

# Step 2: Test again to see if it worked
npm run test:cli

# Step 3: Test everything to make sure nothing broke
npm test

docs.title: Scenario 4: Something is Broken
docs.text:
Goal: Fix weird errors or corrupted dependencies

# Nuclear option: Fresh start
npm run reset

# Wait for reinstall...

# Test that it works now
npm test

Common reasons you'd do this: - "Module not found" errors - "Cannot find package" errors - Things that worked yesterday don't work today - After pulling changes from git

docs.title: Scenario 5: Preparing for Release
docs.text:
Goal: Build the final app to share with others

# Step 1: Make sure everything works
npm test

# Step 2: Build the app
npm run build:all

# Step 3: Find your built app
ls app/dist/

Result: You'll have a .dmg file (Mac) or .exe (Windows) you can distribute

docs.title: 📊 Part 6: Command Cheat Sheet (Print This!)
docs.text: Command Quick Description Use When npm run dev Run app in dev mode Developing app npm run dev:cli Test CLI features Developing CLI npm test Test everything Before committing npm run test:app Test app only Quick app check npm run test:cli Test CLI only Quick CLI check npm run build Build app for release Making distributable npm run clean Delete all installs Need fresh start npm run reset Clean + reinstall Fix weird errors

docs.title: 🎯 Part 7: Practice Exercise (5 minutes)
docs.text: Let's practice! Follow these steps:

docs.title: Exercise 1: Your First Test
docs.text:
# 1. Test the CLI (safest to start with)
npm run test:cli

# Did you see this?
# ✅ All status tests passed!

✅ Success! You just ran your first monorepo command!

docs.title: Exercise 2: Understanding Workspaces
docs.text:
# 1. Test ONLY the app
npm run test:app

# 2. Test ONLY the CLI
npm run test:cli

# 3. Test BOTH
npm test

Notice: The third command runs both of the first two!

docs.title: Exercise 3: Check What's Available
docs.text:
# See all available commands
npm run

Look for: - All the commands we learned - They're grouped by action (dev, test, build, etc.)

docs.title: 🚨 Common Mistakes & How to Avoid Them
Mistake 1: Forgetting the Colon
docs.text:
# ❌ Wrong
npm run testcli

# ✅ Right
npm run test:cli

Remember: Action:workspace (with the colon!)

docs.title: Mistake 2: Running in Wrong Directory
docs.text:
# ❌ Wrong (in app/ folder)
cd app/
npm run dev:app  # Won't work!

# ✅ Right (in root folder)
cd /Users/dt/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli/
npm run dev:app  # Works!

Remember: Always run from the root of the project (where the main package.json is)

docs.title: Mistake 3: Not Installing Dependencies First
docs.text:
# ❌ Wrong order
npm run dev     # Error: modules not found

# ✅ Right order
npm install     # Install first
npm run dev     # Then run

Remember: First time? Run npm install before anything else!

docs.title: 🎓 Part 8: What You Learned
docs.text:
Congratulations! You now know:

  • ✅ What a monorepo is (multiple projects in one repo)
  • ✅ The basic pattern (npm run action:workspace)
  • ✅ How to develop (npm run dev)
  • ✅ How to test (npm test)
  • ✅ How to build (npm run build)
  • ✅ How to fix problems (npm run reset)

docs.title: If you want to learn more:
docs.text:
1. Explore the workspaces:
  2. app/README.md - Desktop app documentation
  3. cli/README.md - CLI integration documentation

docs.title: If you get stuck:
docs.text:
1. Try the reset command: 

    npm run reset

  2. Check you're in the right place: 

    pwd
# Should show: /Users/dt/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli

  3. Verify Node version: 

    node --version
# Should show: v18.x.x or higher

docs.title: Why Separate Commands?
docs.text:
Traditional approach: 

# One big test command
npm test
# Tests EVERYTHING (slow!)

Workspace approach: 

# Test just what you changed
npm run test:cli   # Fast! Only CLI
npm run test:app   # Fast! Only app
npm test           # Slow but thorough

Benefit: Faster feedback while developing!

docs.title: Why the Colon Pattern?
docs.text:
The : creates a namespace:

npm run dev:app   # Dev mode for app
npm run dev:cli   # Dev mode for CLI
npm run test:app  # Test app
npm run test:cli  # Test CLI

Pattern recognition: Your brain learns the pattern quickly! - First part = action (dev, test, build) - Second part = target (app, cli, all)

ADHD-friendly: Predictable = easier to remember

docs.title: Why Clean and Reset?
docs.text:
Sometimes node_modules/ gets corrupted: - Interrupted installs - Version conflicts - Cached issues

The fix: 

npm run clean   # Delete everything
npm install     # Fresh start

Shortcut: 

npm run reset   # Does both!

When to use: - After pulling big changes from git - When you get "module not found" errors - When nothing makes sense anymore

docs.text:

npm run dev

# 4. Made changes? Test them

That's it! You're ready to go! 🚀

Can't remember the commands?

Forget which workspace? - app = Desktop application - cli = Command-line tools - No suffix = Usually app (the main thing)

In the zone and don't want to stop?

docs.title: Plugin Management Workflow
docs.text: Quick Answer: flow plugin manages flow-cli extensions. List, create, install, enable/disable plugins to customize your workflow.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The plugin system allows you to extend flow-cli with custom commands, hooks, and workflows without modifying the core codebase.

Common workflows: - Browse and enable bundled plugins - Create your own custom plugins - Install community plugins from GitHub - Share plugins across teams/projects

docs.title: List Available Plugins
docs.text:
# Show enabled plugins
flow plugin list

# Show all discovered plugins (enabled + disabled)
flow plugin list --all
flow plugin list -a

Output example: 

✓ example-plugin   v1.0.0  Enabled
○ my-custom        v0.1.0  Disabled

docs.title: Enable/Disable Plugins
docs.text:
# Enable a plugin
flow plugin enable my-custom

# Disable a plugin
flow plugin disable my-custom

# Reload shell to apply changes
exec zsh

Note: Reload required after enable/disable.

docs.title: Wizard Creation
docs.text:
The easiest way to create a plugin:

flow plugin create my-workflow

Prompts: 

Plugin name: my-workflow
Created: ~/.config/flow/plugins/my-workflow/
  ├── main.zsh
  ├── plugin.json
  └── README.md

docs.title: Manual Creation
docs.text:
Create plugin structure:

mkdir -p ~/.config/flow/plugins/my-plugin
cd ~/.config/flow/plugins/my-plugin

# Create main file
cat > main.zsh << 'EOF'
# My custom plugin

# Register command
my_command() {
  echo "Hello from my plugin!"
}

# Register hook (optional)
flow_hook_register "PreWork" "_my_plugin_pre_work"

_my_plugin_pre_work() {
  local project="$1"
  echo "Starting work on: $project"
}
EOF

# Create metadata
cat > plugin.json << 'EOF'
{
  "name": "my-plugin",
  "version": "0.1.0",
  "description": "My custom flow-cli plugin",
  "author": "Your Name",
  "commands": ["my_command"],
  "hooks": ["PreWork"]
}
EOF

Reload shell: 

exec zsh
flow plugin list  # Should show your plugin

docs.title: From GitHub
docs.text:
# Install from GitHub repo
flow plugin install gh:username/flow-plugin-docker

# Example: Install a workflow plugin
flow plugin install gh:data-wise/flow-plugin-deploy

What happens: 1. Clones repo to ~/.config/flow/plugins/ 2. Auto-loads on next shell reload 3. Commands/hooks become available

docs.title: From Local Directory
docs.text:
# Copy from local path
flow plugin install /path/to/my-plugin

# Example: Install from Downloads
flow plugin install ~/Downloads/team-workflow-plugin

docs.title: Development Mode (Symlink)
docs.text:
For active development, symlink instead of copying:

cd ~/projects/dev-tools/my-flow-plugin
flow plugin install --dev .

Benefits: - Changes reflect immediately (no reinstall) - Edit code in original location - Perfect for testing

docs.title: 1. Create Plugin Structure
docs.text:
flow plugin create my-awesome-tool
cd ~/.config/flow/plugins/my-awesome-tool

docs.title: 2. Implement Your Command
docs.text:
Edit main.zsh:

# Add custom command
my_deploy() {
  local env="${1:-staging}"

  echo "🚀 Deploying to $env..."

  # Your deployment logic
  if [[ "$env" == "production" ]]; then
    if ! _flow_confirm "Deploy to PRODUCTION?"; then
      echo "Cancelled"
      return 1
    fi
  fi

  # Run deployment
  git push origin main
  ssh deploy@server "cd app && git pull && systemctl restart app"

  echo "✅ Deployed to $env"
}

docs.title: 3. Register Hooks (Optional)
docs.text:
Add hook to run before/after flow-cli events:

# Register hook in main.zsh
flow_hook_register "PostFinish" "_my_plugin_post_finish"

_my_plugin_post_finish() {
  local session_note="$1"

  # Send Slack notification
  if command -v slack-cli >/dev/null 2>&1; then
    slack-cli send "#dev" "Session complete: $session_note"
  fi
}

Available hooks: - PreWork - Before starting work session - PostWork - After work session starts - PreFinish - Before finishing session - PostFinish - After finishing session - PreCommand - Before any command - PostCommand - After any command

docs.title: 4. Update Metadata
docs.text:
Edit plugin.json:

{
  "name": "my-awesome-tool",
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "description": "Automated deployment workflows",
  "author": "Your Name <you@example.com>",
  "commands": ["my_deploy"],
  "hooks": ["PostFinish"],
  "dependencies": {
    "tools": ["git", "ssh"],
    "plugins": []
  },
  "config": {
    "default_env": "staging",
    "notify_slack": true
  }
}

docs.title: 5. Test Your Plugin
docs.text:
# Reload shell
exec zsh

# Test command
my_deploy staging

# Check plugin info
flow plugin info my-awesome-tool

# View hooks
flow plugin hooks

docs.title: 6. Share Your Plugin
docs.text:
Option A: GitHub Repository

cd ~/.config/flow/plugins/my-awesome-tool
git init
git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit"
gh repo create flow-plugin-my-awesome-tool --public --source=. --push

Now others can install: 

flow plugin install gh:yourusername/flow-plugin-my-awesome-tool

Option B: Local Distribution

# Package as tarball
cd ~/.config/flow/plugins
tar -czf my-awesome-tool.tar.gz my-awesome-tool/

# Share tarball
# Others extract and install:
tar -xzf my-awesome-tool.tar.gz
flow plugin install ./my-awesome-tool

docs.title: Pattern 1: Project-Type Dispatcher
docs.text:
Add custom dispatcher for your project type:

# main.zsh
py() {
  local cmd="${1:-help}"
  shift 2>/dev/null

  case "$cmd" in
    test)
      pytest tests/ "$@"
      ;;
    run)
      python main.py "$@"
      ;;
    lint)
      ruff check . && mypy .
      ;;
    help)
      echo "py - Python Project Dispatcher"
      echo "  py test   Run pytest"
      echo "  py run    Run main.py"
      echo "  py lint   Run linters"
      ;;
    *)
      echo "Unknown: $cmd"
      return 1
      ;;
  esac
}

docs.title: Pattern 2: Workflow Automation
docs.text:
Automate repetitive workflows:

# main.zsh
flow_plugin_register_command "deploy-all"

deploy-all() {
  echo "🚀 Full deployment workflow..."

  # 1. Run tests
  echo "1/5 Running tests..."
  flow test || return 1

  # 2. Build
  echo "2/5 Building..."
  flow build || return 1

  # 3. Commit
  echo "3/5 Committing..."
  git add . && git commit -m "Deploy: $(date +%Y-%m-%d)"

  # 4. Push
  echo "4/5 Pushing..."
  git push origin main

  # 5. Deploy
  echo "5/5 Deploying..."
  ssh deploy@server "cd app && git pull && ./deploy.sh"

  echo "✅ Deployment complete!"
}

docs.title: Pattern 3: Integration Hooks
docs.text:
Integrate with external services:

# main.zsh
flow_hook_register "PostFinish" "_notify_jira"

_notify_jira() {
  local note="$1"

  # Extract JIRA ticket from note (e.g., "PROJ-123 fix bug")
  local ticket=$(echo "$note" | grep -oE "[A-Z]+-[0-9]+")

  if [[ -n "$ticket" ]]; then
    # Add comment to JIRA ticket
    jira issue comment "$ticket" \
      "Completed work: $note" \
      --comment-format="plain"

    echo "📝 Updated JIRA ticket: $ticket"
  fi
}

docs.title: Pattern 4: Custom Config
docs.text:
Add plugin-specific configuration:

# main.zsh
# Load plugin config from ~/.config/flow/my-plugin.conf
if [[ -f ~/.config/flow/my-plugin.conf ]]; then
  source ~/.config/flow/my-plugin.conf
fi

# Use config
my_deploy() {
  local env="${MY_PLUGIN_DEFAULT_ENV:-staging}"
  local region="${MY_PLUGIN_AWS_REGION:-us-east-1}"

  echo "Deploying to $env in $region..."
}

# Config file example (~/.config/flow/my-plugin.conf):
# MY_PLUGIN_DEFAULT_ENV="production"
# MY_PLUGIN_AWS_REGION="eu-west-1"
# MY_PLUGIN_SLACK_WEBHOOK="https://hooks.slack.com/..."

docs.title: Information Commands
docs.text:
# Show all plugin info
flow plugin info my-plugin

# Show registered hooks
flow plugin hooks

# Show plugin search paths
flow plugin path

docs.title: Removal
docs.text:
# Remove plugin (with confirmation)
flow plugin remove my-plugin

# Force remove without confirmation
flow plugin remove -f my-plugin

# Note: Cannot remove bundled plugins, only disable them
flow plugin disable bundled-plugin

docs.title: Search Paths (Priority Order)
docs.text:
1. User plugins: ~/.config/flow/plugins/
  2. Bundled plugins: $FLOW_PLUGIN_DIR/plugins/ (flow-cli installation)

docs.title: Directory Structure
docs.text:
~/.config/flow/plugins/
├── my-workflow/
│   ├── main.zsh          # Entry point (required)
│   ├── plugin.json       # Metadata (required)
│   ├── README.md         # Documentation
│   ├── lib/              # Library code
│   │   └── helpers.zsh
│   └── completions/      # ZSH completions
│       └── _my_command

docs.title: Issue: Plugin not loaded
docs.text:
Symptoms: command not found: my_command

Causes: 1. Plugin not enabled 2. Shell not reloaded 3. Syntax error in main.zsh

Solutions: 

# Check plugin status
flow plugin list -a

# Enable if disabled
flow plugin enable my-plugin

# Reload shell
exec zsh

# Check for errors
zsh -x ~/.config/flow/plugins/my-plugin/main.zsh

docs.title: Issue: Hook not firing
docs.text:
Symptoms: Hook function not called

Cause: Hook not registered or wrong event name

Solution: 

# View registered hooks
flow plugin hooks

# Verify registration in main.zsh
grep "flow_hook_register" ~/.config/flow/plugins/my-plugin/main.zsh

# Correct event names: PreWork, PostWork, PreFinish, PostFinish

docs.title: Issue: Command conflicts
docs.text:
Symptoms: Wrong command runs (another plugin/builtin)

Cause: Function name collision

Solution: 

# Use plugin prefix in function names
# Bad:  deploy()
# Good: myplugin_deploy()

# Or namespace with underscore
# Good: _my_plugin_deploy()

docs.title: DO ✅
docs.text:
1. Prefix function names 

# Avoid conflicts
_myplugin_helper() { ... }
myplugin_command() { ... }

2. Clean up on disable 

# Add cleanup function
_myplugin_cleanup() {
  unset -f myplugin_command
  unset MY_PLUGIN_VAR
}

3. Document your plugin 

# Clear README.md with:
# - What it does
# - How to use it
# - Configuration options
# - Examples

4. Version your plugin 

{
  "version": "1.2.0",  // Semantic versioning
  "changelog": {
    "1.2.0": "Added feature X",
    "1.1.0": "Improved performance"
  }
}

docs.title: DON'T ❌
docs.text:
1. Don't modify flow-cli core 

# ❌ Bad: Override core functions
work() { ... }  # Don't do this!

# ✅ Good: Add new commands or hooks
my_work_wrapper() {
  # Custom pre-work logic
  work "$@"
  # Custom post-work logic
}

2. Don't block the shell 

# ❌ Bad: Long-running operations
while true; do
  check_status
  sleep 60
done

# ✅ Good: Background processes or one-shot
(check_status &)

3. Don't assume dependencies 

# ❌ Bad: Direct usage
docker ps

# ✅ Good: Check first
if command -v docker >/dev/null 2>&1; then
  docker ps
else
  echo "Docker not installed"
fi

docs.title: Example 1: AWS Deployment Plugin
docs.text:
# ~/.config/flow/plugins/aws-deploy/main.zsh
aws_deploy() {
  local env="${1:-staging}"
  local region="${AWS_REGION:-us-east-1}"

  echo "🚀 Deploying to AWS ($env, $region)..."

  # Build
  npm run build || return 1

  # Deploy to S3
  aws s3 sync ./dist/ "s3://my-app-$env/" \
    --region "$region" \
    --delete

  # Invalidate CloudFront
  local dist_id=$(aws cloudfront list-distributions \
    --query "DistributionList.Items[?Aliases.Items[?@=='my-app-$env.example.com']].Id | [0]" \
    --output text)

  aws cloudfront create-invalidation \
    --distribution-id "$dist_id" \
    --paths "/*"

  echo "✅ Deployed! https://my-app-$env.example.com"
}

docs.title: Example 2: Slack Notifier Plugin
docs.text:
# ~/.config/flow/plugins/slack-notify/main.zsh
flow_hook_register "PostFinish" "_slack_notify_finish"

_slack_notify_finish() {
  local note="$1"
  local webhook="${SLACK_WEBHOOK:-}"

  [[ -z "$webhook" ]] && return 0

  local project=$(basename "$PWD")
  local user=$(git config user.name || echo "$USER")

  curl -X POST "$webhook" \
    -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
    -d "{
      \"text\": \":white_check_mark: *$user* completed work on *$project*\",
      \"blocks\": [{
        \"type\": \"section\",
        \"text\": {
          \"type\": \"mrkdwn\",
          \"text\": \"$note\"
        }
      }]
    }" \
    --silent --output /dev/null
}

# Config: export SLACK_WEBHOOK="https://hooks.slack.com/..."

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Key Points:

  1. ✅ flow plugin list - See available plugins
  2. ✅ flow plugin create - Create new plugin
  3. ✅ flow plugin install - Install from GitHub/local
  4. ✅ Hooks extend flow-cli behavior without core mods
  5. ✅ Prefix function names to avoid conflicts

Quick workflow:

flow plugin create my-tool

# Develop
cd ~/.config/flow/plugins/my-tool
vim main.zsh

# Test
exec zsh
my_tool_command

# Share
git init && gh repo create --push

docs.title: Project Scope: Personal Productivity & Project Management System
docs.text: Created: 2025-12-20 Revised: 2025-12-20 (removed MCP hub, added architecture) Status: Active Type: Personal Productivity Tool

docs.title: Objective
docs.text:
Build a personal productivity and project management system that eliminates context-switching overhead for managing 30+ simultaneous projects across R packages, teaching, research, and development.

Core Principle: Integrate with existing dev-tools packages rather than duplicating functionality.

docs.title: Target User
docs.text:
DT (personal productivity tool)

Use Case: Academic developer juggling: - 6 R packages (active development + maintenance) - 3 teaching courses (active + archived) - 11 research projects (various stages) - 16 dev-tools projects (shell automation, CLI tools, etc.)

Pain Points: 1. Context Switching: Losing mental context when switching between projects 2. Project Discovery: Hard to remember all 30+ projects and their status 3. Task Overload: Next actions scattered across projects, no unified view 4. Morning Startup: 10+ minutes to remember what I was working on 5. Dependency Confusion: Unclear which projects depend on others

docs.title: 1. Workflow State Manager ⭐ (PRIMARY)
docs.text:
What It Does: Tracks, persists, and restores workflow state across sessions and projects.

State Tracked: - Session State: Active project, current task, started time - Mental Context: What I was thinking, next steps, blockers - Project State: .STATUS content, git status, recent commits - Work Log: Time tracking, session notes, accomplishments - Environment: Last working directory, git branch

Restoration Flow: 

1. Start shell → Detect last session
2. Prompt: "Resume [project-name]? (Last: 2 hours ago)"
3. If yes:
   - cd to project directory
   - Show last context (what you were doing)
   - Display next actions from .STATUS
   - Ready to work in <30 seconds

Integration: - Uses vendored functions from zsh-claude-workflow (~300 lines ported) - Optionally coordinates with aiterm for terminal context switching (if installed) - Stores session state in ~/.local/share/flow-cli/sessions/ - Standalone - No external dependencies required

docs.title: 2. Project Dashboard ⭐ (CORE VISIBILITY)
docs.text:
What It Does: Displays comprehensive overview of all projects at a glance.

Dashboard View: 

═══════════════════════════════════════════════
Personal Projects Overview (32 total)

docs.title: 3. Project Dependency Tracker ⭐ (COORDINATION)
docs.text:
What It Does: Maps relationships between projects to understand impact of changes.

Tracked Relationships: - Depends On: Project requires another (e.g., rmediation depends on medfit) - Used By: Project is used by another (e.g., zsh-claude-workflow used by aiterm) - Related To: Projects in same ecosystem (e.g., all mediationverse packages) - Blocks: Project blocked by another (e.g., probmed blocked by reviewer feedback)

Use Cases: - "What projects will be affected if I update medfit?" - "Why is probmed paused?" → "Blocked by reviewer feedback on sensitivity" - "Show me all projects in mediationverse ecosystem"

docs.title: 4. Multi-Project Task Aggregation
docs.text:
What It Does: Aggregates next actions across all projects into unified task list.

Task Views: - By Priority: P0 (urgent) → P3 (someday) - By Effort: Quick wins (<30 min) → Long projects (>4 hours) - By Category: R packages, teaching, research, dev-tools - By Date: Due today, this week, this month

Example Output: 

Quick Wins (< 30 min):
  ⚡ rmediation: Fix typo in README
  ⚡ stat-440: Upload answer key
  ⚡ zsh-config: Update CLAUDE.md

Medium Tasks (1-2 hours):
  🔧 medfit: Write new vignette
  🔧 aiterm: Test Python 3.12 compatibility

Long Projects (> 4 hours):
  🏗️ probmed: Respond to all reviewer comments
  🏗️ obs-cli: Complete simplification phase

docs.title: Technical Decisions
docs.text:
1. Session Auto-save Frequency
  2. Every command? 15 minutes? On idle?

  3. Recommendation: Save on finish, auto-save every 15 min, prompt on new shell

  4. Project Discovery Scope

  5. Scan all of ~/projects/ or require manual registration?

  6. Recommendation: Auto-scan with manual opt-out (.zsh-ignore file)

  7. Dependency Definition

  8. Manual config or auto-detect from imports?
  9. Recommendation: Start manual, add auto-detection later

docs.title: Integration Decisions
docs.text:
1. aiterm Coordination
  2. Auto-call or user opt-in?

  3. Recommendation: Auto-call if installed, silent skip if not

  4. Session Storage Location

  5. ~/.zsh-sessions/ vs ~/.local/share/flow-cli/?
  6. Recommendation: ~/.local/share/flow-cli/ (XDG-compliant)

  • Status: What stage is the project in?
  • active = Currently working on
  • ready = Ready to start
  • paused = On hold

  • blocked = Waiting for something

  • Priority: How urgent?

  • P0 = Critical (do today!)
  • P1 = Important (this week)

  • P2 = Normal (when you can)

  • Task: What's the next action?

  • Be specific: "Run simulation" not "Work on it"

  • Progress: How far along? (0-100%)

docs.title: ❓ Common Questions
docs.text:
Q: Where is my project data stored? A: In each project's .STATUS file.

Q: What if I don't have a .STATUS file? A: Use status <project> --create to create one.

Q: Can I edit .STATUS manually? A: Yes, but use status command - it's easier!

Q: What if I have many projects? A: Use category filters: dash teaching

Q: How does just-start pick? A: Priority order: P0 active → P1 active → any active → most recent

Q: Can I use this with my existing workflow? A: Yes! It works with work, r, cc, qu, etc.
