docs.title: 🧠 ADHD-Friendly Workflows - Quick Wins Guide
docs.text:
Focus: Top 10 highest-impact workflows for daily R package development

Read Time: 5 minutes | Apply Time: Immediate Last Updated: 2025-12-21 (Updated for 28-alias system)

docs.title: 📋 Table of Contents
docs.text:
# Workflow Time Load Use When 1 Quick Test 5 min 🟢 Made code changes 2 Load + Test 5 min 🟢 Fresh start on package 3 Doc + Test 8 min 🟢 Changed function docs 4 Full Check 60 min 🟡 Before git commit 5 Quick Commit 3 min 🟢 Ready to save work 6 Fix Failing Tests varies 🟡 Tests are red 7 Context Check 30 sec 🟢 Lost context 8 Focus Mode setup 🟢 Need concentration 9 Start Feature 2 min 🟢 Beginning new work 10 Emergency Recovery varies 🔴 Something broke 11 Git Feature Workflow 2 min 🟢 Feature branches 12 Worktrees 1 min 🟢 Parallel development

Cognitive Load: 🟢 Easy | 🟡 Medium | 🔴 Hard

docs.title: 1️⃣ Quick Test Cycle
docs.text: When: You made code changes and want quick feedback Time: ~5 minutes | Load: 🟢 Easy | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Commands
docs.text: rtest                # Run all tests

docs.title: Visual Flow
docs.text: Code changes → rtest → 2-4 min wait → ✅ Green or ❌ Red

docs.title: Decision Points
docs.text:
• ✅ All green → Continue coding
  • ❌ Some red → Fix and re-run rtest
  • 🔴 Many red → Run rload then rtest to reload + test

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Set a 5-min timer while tests run (use focus 5) 💡 Tests too slow? Focus on specific test files 💡 Leave tests running and switch tasks (ADHD-friendly!)

docs.title: What Could Go Wrong?
docs.text:
• Tests hang → Ctrl+C to cancel, check for infinite loops
  • All tests fail → Run rpkg to verify you're in right package

docs.title: 2️⃣ Load + Test (Atomic)
docs.text: When: Fresh start, want to verify everything loads and works Time: ~5 minutes | Load: 🟢 Easy | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Commands
docs.text: rload && rtest       # Load then test

docs.title: Visual Flow
docs.text: Start work → rload && rtest → Package loads → Tests run → ✅ or ❌

docs.title: Why This Works (ADHD-Optimized)
docs.text:
• Automated sequence → No decision fatigue
  • Clear output → Green = go, Red = stop
  • Verifies everything → Load + tests in one go

docs.title: When to Use
docs.text:
• 🌅 Morning start → Verify yesterday's work still works
  • 🔄 After git pull → Check if team changes broke anything
  • 🧹 After cleanup → Confirm nothing broke

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Combine with coffee break - perfect timing! 💡 First command of the day ritual 💡 Bookmark this as your "good morning" command

docs.title: 3️⃣ Document + Test
docs.text: When: You changed function documentation (roxygen comments) Time: ~8 minutes | Load: 🟢 Easy | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Commands
docs.text: rdoc && rtest        # Document then test

docs.title: Visual Flow
docs.text: Change @param docs → rdoc && rtest → Docs regenerate → Tests run → ✅

docs.title: What This Does
docs.text:
1. ⏱️ [3-5s] Regenerates .Rd files from roxygen
  2. ⏱️ [3-5s] Updates NAMESPACE exports
  3. ⏱️ [2-4min] Runs all tests

docs.title: Common Scenario
docs.text:
You: Added new function parameter
You: Updated @param documentation
Run: rdoc && rtest
Result: Documentation updated + tests verify it works

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Always run after changing ANY roxygen comment 💡 Catches missing @export tags early 💡 Faster than full rcheck

docs.title: Safety Checks
docs.text:
• 🟢 Safe - only regenerates docs
  • Auto-backs up NAMESPACE (devtools handles this)

docs.title: 4️⃣ Full Check (Before Commit)
docs.text: When: Ready to commit, need to verify everything is perfect Time: ~60 minutes | Load: 🟡 Medium | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
rcycle               # Full cycle: doc → test → check
# OR (step by step)
rdoc && rtest && rcheck

docs.title: Visual Flow
docs.text: Ready to commit → rcycle → 60 min wait → ✅ 0 errors/warnings/notes

docs.title: What This Does
docs.text:
1. ⏱️ [5s] Documents package
  2. ⏱️ [2-4min] Runs tests
  3. ⏱️ [30-60min] Full R CMD check

docs.title: ADHD Strategy for Long Wait
docs.text:
• ⏰ Set timer → focus 60 for focus timer
  • 🎯 Switch context → Work on different package
  • ☕ Take break → Perfect time for lunch/walk
  • 📧 Other tasks → Email, admin work

docs.title: Decision Points
docs.text:
• ✅ 0 errors, 0 warnings, 0 notes → COMMIT! 🎉
  • ⚠️ Warnings/notes → Investigate (might be OK)
  • ❌ Errors → Fix, run rcheck again

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Run this before ANY git commit 💡 Use rcheckfast for quicker check (skips examples/vignettes) 💡 NEVER commit with errors

docs.title: What Could Go Wrong?
docs.text:
• Check fails → Read error messages carefully
  • Takes forever → Normal! R CMD check is thorough
  • Interrupted → Just re-run to continue

docs.title: 5️⃣ Quick Commit Workflow
docs.text: When: Tests pass, ready to save work to git Time: ~3 minutes | Load: 🟢 Easy | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
# Option 1: Quick (if already checked)
git add . && git commit -m "message"

# Option 2: Safe (docs + tests + commit)
rdoc && rtest && git add . && git commit -m "message"

# Option 3: Ultra-safe (full check + commit)
rdoc && rtest && rcheck && git add . && git commit -m "message"

docs.title: Visual Flow
docs.text: Code ready → git commit → Done in 30s

docs.title: Commit Message Templates
docs.text:
# Feature
git commit -m "feat: add sensitivity analysis function"

# Bug fix
git commit -m "fix: handle NA values in mediation estimate"

# Documentation
git commit -m "docs: update README with new examples"

# Tests
git commit -m "test: add tests for interaction effects"

# Refactor
git commit -m "refactor: simplify bootstrap algorithm"

docs.title: Decision Tree
docs.text:
Did you run rcheck?
├─ Yes → git add . && git commit -m "message"
├─ No → rdoc && rtest then commit (safer)
└─ Not sure → Full check first (safest)

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Commit often (every 30-60 min of work) 💡 Small commits = easier to undo 💡 Use clear messages (future you will thank you!)

docs.title: Safety Checks
docs.text:
• Always run tests before committing
  • Can undo with git reset HEAD~1 if needed

docs.title: 6️⃣ Fix Failing Tests
docs.text: When: Tests are red, need to debug Time: Varies | Load: 🟡 Medium | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Step 1: Identify the Problem (2 min)
docs.text:
rtest                # Run tests, read error messages

Look for:

  • Which test file failed? (test-*.R)
  • Which expectation failed? (expect_equal, etc.)
  • What was expected vs actual?

docs.title: Step 2: Run Single Test (1 min)
docs.text:
# Run specific test file in R:
devtools::test_file("tests/testthat/test-myfunction.R")

docs.title: Step 3: Interactive Debugging (varies)
docs.text:
rload                # Load package
# Then in R console:
# debug(myfunction)
# Run test interactively

docs.title: Step 4: Fix and Verify (2 min)
docs.text:
# Fix the code
rtest                # Re-run all tests

docs.title: Common Test Failures
docs.text:
1. "Error: object not found"

  • Cause: Function not exported or loaded
  • Fix: Add @export tag, run rdoc && rtest

2. "Expected X but got Y"

  • Cause: Logic error or outdated test
  • Fix: Check function logic or update test

3. "Test times out"

  • Cause: Infinite loop or very slow code
  • Fix: Add timeout or optimize code

docs.title: ADHD-Friendly Debug Loop
docs.text:
1. Read error (30s)
2. Hypothesize fix (1 min)
3. Make ONE small change
4. Test immediately with `rtest`
5. Repeat until green

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Only fix ONE test at a time 💡 Use browser() for interactive debugging 💡 Take breaks if frustrated

docs.title: 7️⃣ Where Am I? (Context Check)
docs.text: When: Lost context, can't remember what you were doing Time: ~30 seconds | Load: 🟢 Easy | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
pwd                  # Show current directory
rpkg                 # Package info & status
git status           # Check git status

docs.title: Visual Output
docs.text:
rpkg → Shows:
- 📦 R package name + version
- 📊 Package description
- 🔧 Git branch

docs.title: Quick Recovery Checklist
docs.text:
• [ ] Run pwd → See where you are
  • [ ] Run rpkg → Package information
  • [ ] Run git status → Check git status
  • [ ] Check .STATUS file for next action

docs.title: Common Scenarios
docs.text:
"I forgot what I was working on"

pwd                  # Current directory
rpkg                 # Package info
cat .STATUS          # Check status file

"I don't remember what this package does"

rpkg                 # Package info
cat DESCRIPTION      # Read full description

"Did I make changes?"

git status           # Git status
git diff             # See changes

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Start every session with rpkg 💡 Keep .STATUS file updated 💡 Use git status frequently

docs.title: 8️⃣ Focus Mode (Deep Work)
docs.text: When: Need concentration, minimize distractions Time: Setup < 1 min | Load: 🟢 Easy | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
focus                # Minimize distractions
focus 25             # Focus + 25-min timer (Pomodoro)
unfocus              # Restore notifications

docs.title: What focus Does
docs.text:
1. ✅ Turns off macOS notifications
  2. ✅ Closes Slack, Mail, Messages
  3. ✅ Starts optional timer
  4. ✅ Announces when session ends

docs.title: Visual Flow
docs.text: Need focus → focus 25 → Work uninterrupted → Timer alert → Break

docs.title: Recommended Focus Workflows
docs.text:
Pomodoro (25 min)

f25                  # 25-minute focus timer
# Work for 25 min
# Timer alerts when done
# Take 5-min break

Deep Work (50 min)

f50                  # 50-minute deep work timer
# Work for 50 min
# Timer alerts when done
# Take 10-15 min break

Custom Duration

focus 90             # Custom 90-minute session
# Work until timer ends

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Use f25 or f50 aliases for common durations 💡 Use during rcheck 60-min wait 💡 Take regular breaks to maintain focus

docs.title: After Focus Session
docs.text:
# Update status and commit progress
git add . && git commit -m "Progress on X"

docs.title: 9️⃣ Start New Feature
docs.text: When: Beginning new function or feature Time: ~2 minutes | Load: 🟢 Easy | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: [ ] 1. Context Setup (30s)
docs.text:
pwd                  # Verify location
rpkg                 # Check package info
git status           # Check git status

docs.title: [ ] 2. Create Function File (30s)
docs.text:
# Create R/myfunction.R manually
# OR use usethis:
usethis::use_r("myfunction")

docs.title: [ ] 3. Create Test File (30s)
docs.text:
# Create tests/testthat/test-myfunction.R
# OR use usethis:
usethis::use_test("myfunction")

docs.title: [ ] 4. Document Template (30s)
docs.text:
Add roxygen skeleton:

#' Function Title
#'
#' @param x Description
#' @return Description
#' @export
#' @examples
#' myfunction(x = 1)
myfunction <- function(x) {
  # TODO: Implement
}

docs.title: [ ] 5. First Test (30s)
docs.text:
test_that("myfunction works", {
  result <- myfunction(x = 1)
  expect_true(!is.null(result))
})

docs.title: [ ] 6. Verify Setup
docs.text:
rload && rtest       # Load + test
# Should load successfully, test might fail (that's OK!)

docs.title: Quick Start Template
docs.text:
# Create files, then verify:
rload && rtest

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Start with test first (TDD approach) 💡 Make smallest working version 💡 Commit early: git commit -m "feat: add myfunction skeleton"

docs.title: 🔟 What Did I Break? (Emergency Recovery)
docs.text: When: Something broke and you're not sure what Time: Varies | Load: 🔴 Hard | Safety: 🟡 Careful

docs.title: Step 1: Assess Damage
docs.text:
pwd                  # Where am I?
git status           # What changed?
rtest                # Do tests pass?

docs.title: Step 2: Identify Problem
docs.text:
Tests failing?

rtest                # Run tests
# Read error messages carefully
# Jump to workflow #6 (Fix Failing Tests)

Package won't load?

rload                # Try to load
# Read error messages
# Common: syntax error, missing dependency

Git issues?

git status           # Git status
git log --oneline -5 # Recent commits

docs.title: Option A: Recent Changes (Most Common)
docs.text:
# Undo last commit (keeps changes)
git reset HEAD~1
# Fix the issue
rtest                # Verify tests pass
git add . && git commit -m "fix: ..."

docs.title: Option B: Code Error
docs.text:
# Use editor to fix syntax error
# Then:
rload                # Try loading again
rtest                # Run tests

docs.title: Option C: Clean Build (Last Resort)
docs.text:
# Clean and rebuild
rm -rf man/ NAMESPACE
rdoc && rtest        # Regenerate docs + test

docs.title: Prevention Checklist
docs.text:
• ✅ Run tests before commits
  • ✅ Commit frequently (small changes)
  • ✅ Use version control
  • ✅ Test after major changes

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Don't panic - almost everything is reversible 💡 Read error messages slowly (pause before acting) 💡 Ask for help: cc (Claude Code) or colleagues

docs.title: When to Ask for Help
docs.text:
• 🔴 Spent > 30 min stuck
  • 🔴 Don't understand error message
  • 🔴 Afraid of making it worse

docs.title: 🎯 Quick Decision Tree
docs.text:
Use this when you're not sure what to do:

What do you want to do?

├─ Just made code changes
│  └─ Run: rtest
│
├─ Starting work on package
│  └─ Run: rload && rtest
│
├─ Changed documentation
│  └─ Run: rdoc && rtest
│
├─ Ready to commit
│  ├─ Did full check? → git add . && git commit -m "msg"
│  └─ Not sure → rcheck then commit
│
├─ Tests are failing
│  └─ See workflow #6 (Fix Failing Tests)
│
├─ Don't know where I am
│  └─ Run: rpkg
│
├─ Need to focus
│  └─ Run: f25 or f50
│
├─ Starting new feature
│  └─ See workflow #9 (Start New Feature)
│
└─ Something broke
   └─ See workflow #10 (Emergency Recovery)

docs.title: ⏱️ Time-Based Quick Reference
docs.text:
"I have 5 minutes"

  • Run rtest (quick test)
  • Check rpkg (context)
  • Review .STATUS file

"I have 15 minutes"

  • Run rload && rtest
  • Fix one failing test
  • Quick commit

"I have 30 minutes"

  • Run rdoc && rtest
  • Start new feature
  • Focus session with f25

"I have 60+ minutes"

  • Run full rcheck
  • Deep work with f50 or focus 90
  • Multiple test-fix cycles

docs.title: Managing Wait Times
docs.text:
• Tests running (2-4 min)? → Perfect for coffee/bathroom
  • R CMD check (60 min)? → Switch to different task
  • Stuck debugging? → Take a 5-min break

docs.title: Preventing Context Loss
docs.text:
• Start every session: Check rpkg and .STATUS
  • End every session: Update .STATUS file
  • Commit frequently: Small commits = less to lose

docs.title: Reducing Decision Fatigue
docs.text:
• Use command chains: rload && rtest, rdoc && rtest
  • Follow workflows: Don't invent, follow the guide
  • Set timers: f25, f50, or focus commands

docs.title: Building Habits
docs.text:
• Morning ritual: rpkg → rload && rtest → check output
  • Before commit: rcheck → wait → commit
  • After break: rpkg → review .STATUS → resume

docs.title: 🚨 Common Mistakes & Fixes
docs.text: Mistake Why Bad Fix Skip testing Breaks accumulate Always run rtest No documentation Future you confused Run rdoc && rtest after changes Large commits Hard to debug Commit every 30-60 min Commit with errors Broken code in history Always test first Work without breaks Burnout, mistakes Use f25 or f50 timers Ignore .STATUS Lose context Update .STATUS regularly

docs.title: Connects to .STATUS Files
docs.text:
• Keep .STATUS updated with current progress
  • Check .STATUS at start of each session
  • Use for context when switching projects

docs.title: Works with Help System
docs.text:
• Forgot command? Check the alias reference card
  • Need reminder? Review this quick wins guide
  • Full reference → See ALIAS-REFERENCE-CARD.md

docs.text:
• f25 / f50 → Pomodoro/deep work timers
  • focus <min> → Custom duration focus sessions
  • win → Log accomplishments

docs.title: 🎉 Success Patterns
docs.text:
Morning Start (5 min)

rpkg → rload && rtest → Coffee while tests run → Review results → Code

Quick Feature (30 min)

f25 → Create files → Code → rdoc && rtest

Pre-Commit (65 min)

rcheck → f60 focus session → Switch tasks → Check results → commit

End of Day (5 min)

rtest → git commit -m "wip: progress on X" → Update .STATUS for tomorrow

docs.title: 1️⃣1️⃣ Git Feature Branch Workflow (v4.1.0+)
docs.text: When: Working on new features, hotfixes, or any code changes Time: ~2 minutes | Load: 🟢 Easy | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
# Start a feature
g feature start auth-improvements

# Work on your feature...
g add . && g commit "Add OAuth2 support"

# Stay synced with dev
g feature sync

# Finish: push + create PR
g feature finish

docs.title: Visual Flow
docs.text: Start → feature start → code → commit → sync → finish → PR → merge

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text: Command What It Does g feature start <name> Create feature branch from dev g feature sync Rebase feature onto dev g feature list List feature/hotfix branches g feature finish Push + create PR to dev g promote Create PR: feature → dev g release Create PR: dev → main g feature prune Delete merged branches

docs.title: Workflow Guard
docs.text:
The workflow guard blocks direct pushes to protected branches:

# Blocked ❌
git checkout main && g push   # Direct push to main blocked

# Allowed ✅
g feature start my-fix        # Create feature branch
g push                        # Push feature branch OK
g promote                     # Create PR instead

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Run g feature sync daily to avoid merge conflicts 💡 Use g feature finish to push + create PR in one step 💡 Clean up with g feature prune weekly

docs.title: 1️⃣2️⃣ Parallel Development with Worktrees (v4.1.0+)
docs.text: When: Need to work on multiple features simultaneously Time: ~1 minute | Load: 🟢 Easy | Safety: 🟢 Safe

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
# Create worktree for a branch
wt create feature/auth

# List all worktrees
wt list

# Navigate to worktrees folder
wt

# Clean up stale worktrees
wt clean

docs.title: Visual Flow
docs.text: Main work → wt create feature/b → Parallel work → wt clean

docs.title: Claude Code + Worktrees
docs.text:
Launch Claude in a dedicated worktree:

# Launch Claude in worktree (creates if needed)
cc wt feature/auth

# Pick from existing worktrees
cc wt pick

# Worktree + YOLO mode
cc wt yolo feature/risky

# Worktree + Plan mode
cc wt plan feature/complex

docs.title: Aliases
docs.text: Alias Expands To Description ccw cc wt Worktree + Claude ccwy cc wt yolo Worktree + YOLO mode ccwp cc wt pick Worktree picker

docs.title: When to Use Worktrees
docs.text:
• 🔀 Parallel features - Work on feature-a while feature-b runs tests
  • 👀 Code review - Review PR in isolated directory
  • 🧪 Experiments - Try risky changes without affecting main work
  • ⚡ Quick fixes - Hotfix while feature work continues

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text: 💡 Each worktree is completely isolated - no stashing needed 💡 Worktrees persist after Claude exits 💡 Use wt clean regularly to remove stale worktrees

docs.title: Git Worktrees with Claude Code
docs.text: Level: Intermediate Time: 15 minutes Goal: Use git worktrees for isolated, parallel Claude Code development

docs.title: What This Guide Covers
docs.text:
Learn how to combine git worktrees with Claude Code for safe, parallel development:

  • ✅ What worktrees are and why they're better than branches for experiments
  • ✅ CC dispatcher integration with unified mode-first pattern
  • ✅ Complete workflows for experimentation and parallel work
  • ✅ Safety practices with YOLO mode in worktrees
  • ✅ Session tracking to see which worktrees have active Claude sessions

docs.title: The Problem with Branch Switching
docs.text:
Traditional git workflow: 

git checkout -b experiment-refactor
# Work on experiment...
# Oh no, urgent bug fix needed!
git stash                  # Save work
git checkout main          # Switch branch
git checkout -b hotfix     # Create fix branch
# Fix bug...
git checkout experiment-refactor  # Back to experiment
git stash pop              # Restore work

Issues: - ⚠️ Constant stashing/unstashing - ⚠️ Lost context when switching - ⚠️ Can't work on multiple features simultaneously - ⚠️ IDE has to reload files on every branch switch

docs.title: The Worktree Solution
docs.text:
Git worktrees = Multiple working directories for same repo:

~/projects/flow-cli/                      # Main (production)
~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-refactor/       # Experiment 1
~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-hotfix/         # Urgent fix
~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-new-feature/    # Feature work

Benefits: - ✅ Each branch has its own directory - ✅ No branch switching needed - ✅ Work on multiple features in parallel - ✅ IDE stays stable (one project per window) - ✅ Easy cleanup (just delete directory)

docs.title: Create Worktree
docs.text:
# Via flow-cli wt dispatcher
wt create feature/new-auth

# Or via git directly
git worktree add ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-feature-new-auth feature/new-auth

Location: ~/.git-worktrees/<repo>-<branch>/

docs.title: List Worktrees
docs.text:
# Via flow-cli
wt list

# Or via git
git worktree list

Output: 

/Users/dt/projects/flow-cli          abc123 [main]
/Users/dt/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-refactor  def456 [feature/refactor]

docs.title: Remove Worktree
docs.text:
# Via flow-cli
wt remove feature/new-auth

# Or via git
git worktree remove ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-feature-new-auth

docs.title: Unified "Mode First" Pattern
docs.text:
The CC dispatcher now supports consistent mode → target syntax:

# Pattern: cc [mode] [target]
# Modes: (none), yolo, plan, opus, haiku
# Targets: (here), pick, wt <branch>, <project>

docs.title: Basic Worktree Launch
docs.text:
# Launch Claude in worktree (creates if needed)
cc wt feature/refactor

# Pick from existing worktrees
cc wt pick

# List worktrees with session info
cc wt status

docs.title: Mode-First Pattern (NEW!)
docs.text:
YOLO mode: 

cc yolo wt feature/refactor     # Mode → worktree
cc yolo wt pick                 # Mode → worktree picker

Plan mode: 

cc plan wt feature/refactor     # Plan mode in worktree
cc plan wt pick                 # Pick worktree for planning

Model selection: 

cc opus wt experiment/ui        # Opus model in worktree
cc haiku wt feature/docs        # Haiku model in worktree

docs.title: Backward Compatible Pattern
docs.text:
Old syntax still works: 

cc wt yolo feature/refactor     # Target → mode (still works)
cc wt plan feature/refactor     # Target → mode (still works)
cc wt opus experiment/ui        # Target → mode (still works)

Aliases: 

ccw feature/refactor            # cc wt
ccwy feature/refactor           # cc wt yolo
ccwp                            # cc wt pick
ccy                             # cc yolo

docs.title: Workflow 1: Safe Experimentation with YOLO Mode
docs.text:
Scenario: Want to refactor entire commands/ directory without risk

# 1. Create worktree with YOLO mode (mode-first)
cc yolo wt experiment/commands-refactor

# Claude launches in:
# ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-experiment-commands-refactor/
# With: --dangerously-skip-permissions

# 2. Give Claude instructions
> Refactor all commands/*.zsh files to use modern ZSH patterns and consistent error handling

# 3. Monitor from main project (separate terminal)
cd ~/projects/flow-cli
watch -n 2 'git -C ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-experiment-commands-refactor diff --stat'

# 4. Review when done
cd ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-experiment-commands-refactor
git diff --stat
git diff commands/

# 5. Decision point
# Option A: Success! Merge to main
cd ~/projects/flow-cli
git checkout main
git merge experiment/commands-refactor
git push

# Option B: Failed experiment - just delete
wt remove experiment/commands-refactor
# All changes gone, main repo untouched

Why this works: - ✅ YOLO mode = no permission prompts - ✅ Worktree = main repo stays safe - ✅ Easy cleanup if experiment fails - ✅ No branch switching needed

docs.title: Workflow 2: Parallel Feature Development
docs.text:
Scenario: Working on two features simultaneously

# Terminal 1: Feature A (authentication)
cc wt feature/new-auth
cd ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-feature-new-auth
# Work on auth...

# Terminal 2: Feature B (documentation)
cc plan wt feature/docs-update
cd ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-feature-docs-update
# Work on docs with plan mode...

# Terminal 3: Main project (review/testing)
cd ~/projects/flow-cli
git status
pytest

Benefits: - Each feature isolated - No context switching - Can test changes independently - Main repo available for review

docs.title: Workflow 3: Quick Hotfix While Working
docs.text:
Scenario: Urgent bug fix needed during feature work

# Already working in feature worktree
cd ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-feature-refactor
# Claude session active...

# Urgent bug reported! Don't switch context
# Terminal 2: Create hotfix worktree
cc wt hotfix/picker-crash

# Fix bug in hotfix worktree
cd ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-hotfix-picker-crash
# Make fix, test, commit

# Merge hotfix to main
cd ~/projects/flow-cli
git checkout main
git merge hotfix/picker-crash
git push

# Back to feature work (untouched!)
cd ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-feature-refactor
# Continue where you left off

docs.title: Workflow 4: Experimenting with Different Approaches
docs.text:
Scenario: Not sure which refactoring approach is best

# Create 3 experimental worktrees
cc wt experiment/approach-a
cc wt experiment/approach-b
cc wt experiment/approach-c

# Try different approaches in parallel
# Terminal 1: Approach A (functional)
cd ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-experiment-approach-a
cc yolo
> Refactor commands/ using pure functional approach

# Terminal 2: Approach B (OOP)
cd ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-experiment-approach-b
cc yolo
> Refactor commands/ using object-oriented patterns

# Terminal 3: Approach C (modular)
cd ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-experiment-approach-c
cc yolo
> Refactor commands/ into small, composable modules

# Compare results
wt status                    # See which has recent sessions
cd ~/projects/flow-cli
git diff experiment/approach-a..main -- commands/ | wc -l
git diff experiment/approach-b..main -- commands/ | wc -l
git diff experiment/approach-c..main -- commands/ | wc -l

# Pick winner, delete losers
git merge experiment/approach-b
wt remove experiment/approach-a
wt remove experiment/approach-c

docs.title: Check Worktree Sessions
docs.text:
# Show all worktrees with Claude session info
cc wt status

Output: 

Worktrees with Claude Session Info
────────────────────────────────────────

🟢 ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-refactor     [feature/refactor] (2026-01-01 14:32)
🟡 ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-experiment   [experiment/new]    (old session)
⚪ ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-hotfix       [hotfix/bug]

Legend: 🟢 Recent session (< 24h) | 🟡 Old session | ⚪ No session

Indicators: - 🟢 Recent session (< 24 hours ago) - 🟡 Old session (> 24 hours ago) - ⚪ No Claude session in this worktree

Use case: Find where you were last working

docs.title: Pick with Session Priority
docs.text:
# FZF picker shows worktrees
cc wt pick

Display includes: - Session indicators (🟢/🟡) - Branch names - Recent activity timestamps

docs.title: 1. Worktrees Don't Replace Git Safety
docs.text:
Still required: 

# Before YOLO in worktree
cd ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-experiment
git status                    # Ensure clean
git log -1                    # Check starting point

# During work
watch -n 2 'git diff --stat'  # Monitor changes

# After work
git diff                      # Review ALL changes
git add -p                    # Stage selectively

docs.title: 2. Cleanup Regularly
docs.text:
Find stale worktrees: 

wt list
# Or
git worktree list

# Remove finished experiments
wt remove experiment/old-idea
wt remove feature/completed

docs.title: 3. Keep Main Clean
docs.text:
Never work directly in main worktree during experiments: 

# Good: Separate worktree for experiment
cc yolo wt experiment/risky-change

# Bad: YOLO mode in main project
cd ~/projects/flow-cli
cc yolo                       # ❌ Too risky!

docs.title: 4. Name Worktrees Clearly
docs.text:
Good names: - experiment/commands-refactor - Purpose clear - feature/oauth-login - Feature clear - hotfix/picker-crash - Type clear

Bad names: - test - What test? - tmp - Temporary what? - new - New what?

docs.title: 5. One Claude Session Per Worktree
docs.text:
Avoid confusion: 

# Good: One session
cd ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-feature-auth
cc yolo

# Bad: Multiple sessions in same worktree (confusing)
# Terminal 1
cc yolo wt feature/auth
# Terminal 2
cc yolo wt feature/auth      # ❌ Two sessions, same files

docs.title: Shared Worktree for Team Review
docs.text:
Scenario: Team member wants to review your experimental branch

# You: Create worktree for experiment
cc yolo wt experiment/new-parser

# Commit work
git add -A
git commit -m "WIP: new parser approach"
git push origin experiment/new-parser

# Team member: Clone as worktree
git worktree add ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-experiment-new-parser origin/experiment/new-parser
cd ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-experiment-new-parser
cc  # Review with Claude

docs.title: Worktree for CI/CD Testing
docs.text:
Scenario: Test changes in isolation before merge

# Create worktree from feature branch
cc wt feature/new-feature

# Run full test suite in worktree
cd ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-feature-new-feature
pytest
npm test
./tests/run-all.sh

# CI passes? Merge from main
cd ~/projects/flow-cli
git checkout main
git merge feature/new-feature

# CI fails? Debug in worktree (main untouched)
cd ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-feature-new-feature
cc yolo
> Fix the failing tests

docs.title: Long-Running Experiments
docs.text:
Scenario: Multi-day refactoring project

# Day 1: Start experiment
cc yolo wt experiment/async-rewrite
# Work...
git add -A && git commit -m "Day 1: Convert core functions to async"

# Day 2: Continue (worktree persists)
cd ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-experiment-async-rewrite
cc yolo
# Continue...
git add -A && git commit -m "Day 2: Update tests for async"

# Day 3: Finish
# Continue...
git add -A && git commit -m "Day 3: Documentation and cleanup"

# Review full history
git log experiment/async-rewrite --oneline

# Merge or squash
cd ~/projects/flow-cli
git checkout main
git merge --squash experiment/async-rewrite
git commit -m "feat: migrate to async architecture"

docs.title: Worktree Creation Fails
docs.text:
Error: fatal: 'feature/auth' is already checked out at '...'

Solution: Branch already has a worktree 

# List existing worktrees
wt list

# Remove old worktree if done with it
wt remove feature/auth

# Or use the existing worktree
cd ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-feature-auth

docs.title: Can't Find Worktree
docs.text:
Error: Created worktree but can't remember path

Solution: 

# List all worktrees with full paths
wt list

# Or use picker
cc wt pick

docs.title: Worktree Out of Sync
docs.text:
Problem: Worktree doesn't have latest changes

Solution: Pull in worktree 

cd ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-feature-auth
git status
git pull origin feature/auth

docs.title: Session Indicator Wrong
docs.text:
Problem: 🟢 indicator shows but no active session

Explanation: Indicator shows last session time, not current session - 🟢 = Session within 24 hours (may be closed now) - Check .claude/*.json files for actual session data

docs.title: Disk Space Issues
docs.text:
Problem: Too many old worktrees

Solution: Cleanup 

# List all worktrees
wt list

# Remove old experiments
wt remove experiment/old-1
wt remove experiment/old-2

# Or clean up manually
git worktree prune

docs.title: Comparison: Branches vs Worktrees
docs.text:
Feature Git Branches Git Worktrees Isolation Switch working tree Separate directories Parallel work ❌ No (must stash) ✅ Yes IDE stability ❌ Reloads on switch ✅ Stable Disk usage ✅ Minimal ⚠️ More (separate copies) Cleanup Delete branch Delete directory + branch Best for Sequential work Parallel experiments

When to use branches: - Sequential development - Single developer - Limited disk space

When to use worktrees: - Parallel development - Experimentation (easy cleanup) - Hotfixes during feature work - Team reviews

docs.title: ✅ DO
docs.text:
• ✅ Use worktrees for experiments and risky changes
  • ✅ Combine with YOLO mode for speed + safety
  • ✅ Name worktrees descriptively
  • ✅ Review changes before merging
  • ✅ Clean up finished worktrees
  • ✅ Use session indicators to find active work
  • ✅ Keep one Claude session per worktree

docs.title: ❌ DON'T
docs.text:
• ❌ Use YOLO mode in main project directory
  • ❌ Let worktrees accumulate without cleanup
  • ❌ Forget to commit work in worktrees
  • ❌ Run multiple Claude sessions in same worktree
  • ❌ Use vague names like "test" or "tmp"

docs.title: Create & Launch
docs.text:
cc wt <branch>              # acceptEdits mode
cc yolo wt <branch>         # YOLO mode
cc plan wt <branch>         # Plan mode
cc opus wt <branch>         # Opus model

docs.title: Pick Existing
docs.text:
cc wt pick                  # acceptEdits mode
cc yolo wt pick             # YOLO mode
cc plan wt pick             # Plan mode

docs.title: Status & Management
docs.text:
cc wt status                # Show all with sessions
wt list                     # List all worktrees
wt remove <branch>          # Delete worktree

docs.title: Aliases
docs.text:
ccw <branch>                # cc wt
ccwy <branch>               # cc wt yolo
ccwp                        # cc wt pick
ccy                         # cc yolo

docs.text:

  • CC Dispatcher Reference - Complete command guide

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Git worktrees enable: 1. ✅ Parallel development without branch switching 2. ✅ Safe experimentation with easy cleanup 3. ✅ YOLO mode isolation (fast + safe) 4. ✅ Hotfixes during feature work

Best workflow: - Experiments → cc yolo wt experiment/<name> - Features → cc wt feature/<name> - Hotfixes → cc wt hotfix/<name>

Remember: - Main repo stays clean - Easy cleanup (delete directory) - Session tracking built-in - Works with all CC modes (yolo, plan, opus, haiku)

docs.title: Claude Code Rapid Development Workflow
docs.text: Level: Intermediate Time: 10 minutes Goal: Minimize permission prompts for faster development with Claude Code

docs.title: What This Guide Covers
docs.text:
This guide explains how to reduce interruptions when working with Claude Code, including:

  • ✅ Auto-Accept Edits in VS Code (Shift+Tab method)
  • ✅ CLI YOLO Mode with --dangerously-skip-permissions
  • ✅ Safety practices with git
  • ✅ flow-cli integration for rapid workflows

Important: There is no "YOLO mode" setting in the VS Code extension. The methods here are the actual working approaches.

docs.title: The Reality: Two Different Permission Models
VS Code Extension: Limited Auto-Accept
docs.text:
The VS Code Claude Code extension has its own permission system:

  • ✅ Can auto-accept file edits (Shift+Tab toggle)
  • ❌ Still prompts for read permissions
  • ❌ Still prompts for execute permissions
  • ❌ Still prompts for tool usage

docs.title: CLI: True YOLO Mode
docs.text:
The Claude Code CLI has full permission bypass:

  • ✅ Bypasses all permissions (read, write, execute)
  • ✅ Uses --dangerously-skip-permissions flag
  • ⚠️ Only available via command line, not VS Code extension

docs.title: Method 1: Auto-Accept Edits in VS Code
How to Enable
docs.text:
The VS Code extension has a built-in mode toggle:

Step 1: Open Claude Code chat in VS Code

Step 2: Press Shift+Tab to cycle through modes: - Normal mode - Auto-accept edits ← Stop here - Plan mode

Step 3: Verify mode indicator shows "Auto-accept edits: ON"

docs.title: What It Does
docs.text: Permission Type Auto-Accepted? File edits ✅ Yes File reads ❌ No - still prompts File writes (new) ❌ No - still prompts Execute commands ❌ No - still prompts Tool usage ❌ No - still prompts

docs.title: When to Use
docs.text:
Good for: - ✅ Refactoring existing files - ✅ Code cleanup across multiple files - ✅ Iterative development where you review frequently

Not good for: - ❌ Reading many files (still prompts) - ❌ Running tests/commands (still prompts) - ❌ Truly unattended workflows (use CLI instead)

docs.title: Example Workflow
docs.text:
1. Open VS Code with your project
2. Start Claude Code chat
3. Press Shift+Tab until "Auto-accept edits: ON"
4. Ask: "Refactor commands/work.zsh to use modern ZSH patterns"
5. Claude edits files automatically (no confirmation per edit)
6. Review changes with: git diff
7. Commit or revert as needed

docs.title: How to Enable
docs.text:
The real YOLO mode only exists in the command-line interface:

# This bypasses ALL permissions
claude --dangerously-skip-permissions

docs.title: What It Does
docs.text:
Permission Type Bypassed? File edits ✅ Yes File reads ✅ Yes File writes ✅ Yes Execute commands ✅ Yes Tool usage ✅ Yes

This is the closest to "YOLO mode" - Claude can do anything without asking.

docs.title: Safety Requirements
docs.text:
⚠️ CRITICAL: Only use in isolated environments

Required safeguards: 1. Git repository (for rollback) 2. Clean working tree (can discard changes) 3. Separate branch (not main/production) 4. OR: Dev container/VM (isolated environment)

docs.title: Example Workflow
docs.text:
# 1. Ensure clean git state
git status
git checkout -b experiment-refactor

# 2. Launch Claude Code CLI with YOLO mode
claude --dangerously-skip-permissions

# 3. Give instructions
> Refactor the entire commands/ directory to use modern ZSH patterns

# 4. Monitor with watch command (separate terminal)
watch -n 2 'git diff --stat'

# 5. Review when done
git diff --stat
git diff commands/

# 6. Commit or discard
git add -A && git commit -m "refactor: modernize commands"
# OR
git reset --hard HEAD  # Discard everything

docs.title: Method 3: Dev Container Setup (Advanced)
docs.text: For truly unattended Claude Code in VS Code:

docs.title: Setup Steps
docs.text:
1. Create .devcontainer configuration
  2. Disable firewall (remove postCreateCommand)
  3. Enable passwordless sudo (optional)
  4. Reopen in container
  5. Run CLI with --dangerously-skip-permissions

Why containers? Isolates Claude's actions from your main system.

Reference: Dev Container YOLO Setup

docs.title: CLI YOLO Mode (Implemented)
docs.text:
The cc dispatcher supports true YOLO mode via CLI:

# Launch Claude CLI with YOLO mode
cc yolo                     # HERE (current directory)
cc yolo pick                # Pick project → YOLO
cc yolo <project>           # Direct jump → YOLO
cc yolo wt <branch>         # Worktree → YOLO (NEW!)
cc yolo wt pick             # Pick worktree → YOLO (NEW!)

# Alias
ccy                         # Short for: cc yolo

What it does: Launches claude --dangerously-skip-permissions for true permission bypass.

docs.title: Worktree Integration (Unified Pattern)
docs.text:
Combine YOLO mode with worktrees for safe experimentation:

# Mode-first pattern (NEW!)
cc yolo wt feature/refactor     # YOLO mode in worktree
cc plan wt feature/refactor     # Plan mode in worktree
cc opus wt experiment/new-ui    # Opus model in worktree

# Pick existing worktree
cc yolo wt pick                 # FZF picker → YOLO mode
cc plan wt pick                 # FZF picker → Plan mode

# Backward compatible (still works)
cc wt yolo feature/refactor     # Old pattern
ccwy feature/refactor           # Alias: cc wt yolo

Why worktrees? Isolated environments with easy cleanup:

  • Experiment fails? Delete the worktree
  • Main codebase stays clean
  • No branch switching needed

docs.title: Complete Worktree + YOLO Workflow
docs.text:
# 1. Create worktree with YOLO mode
cc yolo wt experiment/commands-refactor

# Claude launches in isolated worktree with full permissions
# Location: ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-experiment-commands-refactor/

# 2. Monitor from main project (separate terminal)
cd ~/projects/flow-cli
watch -n 2 'git -C ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-experiment-commands-refactor diff --stat'

# 3. Review when done
cd ~/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-experiment-commands-refactor
git diff
git log

# 4. Merge if good, delete if bad
# Good: Merge to main
git checkout main
git merge experiment/commands-refactor

# Bad: Just delete worktree
wt remove experiment/commands-refactor

Safest approach: Worktree + YOLO gives isolation AND speed.

docs.title: 1. Git is Your Safety Net
docs.text:
Always work in a git repository:

# Before YOLO session
git status                    # Ensure clean
git checkout -b yolo-test     # Separate branch

# During YOLO session
watch -n 2 'git diff --stat'  # Monitor changes

# After YOLO session
git diff                      # Review all changes
git add -p                    # Stage selectively
git commit                    # Save good changes

# If things go wrong
git reset --hard HEAD         # Nuclear option

docs.title: 2. Use Worktrees for Isolation
docs.text:
Keep main codebase safe:

# Create isolated worktree
wt create yolo-experiment

# Claude works here
cd ~/projects/.git-worktrees/flow-cli-yolo-experiment
claude --dangerously-skip-permissions

# Experiment fails? Just delete
cd ~/projects/flow-cli
wt remove yolo-experiment

docs.title: 3. Start Small
docs.text:
First YOLO session? Start with low-risk tasks:

✅ Good first tasks: - Update documentation - Add unit tests - Refactor a single module - Format code

❌ Avoid initially: - Rewrite authentication - Change database schema - Modify deployment configs

docs.title: 4. Review Frequently
docs.text:
Don't let Claude make 100 changes unchecked:

# Review every 5-10 operations
git diff --stat               # See what changed
git diff lib/core.zsh         # Review specific file

docs.title: 5. Backup Critical State
docs.text:
Before risky changes:

# Create backup branch
git checkout -b backup-$(date +%Y%m%d)
git checkout main

# Or stash current state
git stash save "pre-yolo-$(date +%Y%m%d-%H%M)"

docs.title: ❌ Myth: VS Code Settings for YOLO Mode
docs.text:
These settings do not exist in the official extension:

{
  "claude-code.yoloMode": true,          // ❌ Fake
  "claude-code.acceptEdits": true,       // ❌ Fake
  "claude-code.autoSave": true,          // ❌ Fake
  "claude-code.showTokenCount": true     // ❌ Fake
}

Why the confusion? These were incorrectly documented earlier. The VS Code extension doesn't have these settings.

docs.title: ❌ Myth: Workspace Files Enable YOLO
docs.text:
Creating a .code-workspace file with fake settings does nothing:

{
  "folders": [{"path": "."}],
  "settings": {
    "claude-code.yoloMode": true  // ❌ Has no effect
  }
}

Reality: The VS Code extension ignores these settings.

docs.title: ❌ Myth: --dangerously-skip-permissions Works in VS Code
docs.text:
The CLI flag does not work when using the VS Code extension:

# This only works in CLI, not VS Code extension
claude --dangerously-skip-permissions

Why? The VS Code extension has its own separate permission system.

docs.title: Comparison: VS Code vs CLI
docs.text: Feature VS Code Extension CLI Auto-accept edits ✅ Shift+Tab ✅ --dangerously-skip-permissions Auto-accept reads ❌ No ✅ Yes Auto-accept writes ❌ No ✅ Yes Auto-accept execute ❌ No ✅ Yes GUI integration ✅ Native VS Code ❌ Terminal only Safety model Built-in prompts User responsibility Best for Interactive development Automated workflows

docs.title: Scenario: Refactor Project Structure
docs.text:
Setup: 

cd ~/projects/flow-cli
git status                    # Clean working tree
git checkout -b refactor-cmds

Option A: VS Code (Auto-Accept Edits) 

# 1. Open in VS Code
code .

# 2. Start Claude Code chat

# 3. Enable auto-accept
Press Shift+Tab → "Auto-accept edits: ON"

# 4. Give instructions
Ask: "Refactor commands/*.zsh to use consistent error handling"

# 5. Review as it works
Open Source Control panel
Watch files change in real-time

# 6. Commit
git add -A
git commit -m "refactor: consistent error handling"

Option B: CLI (True YOLO) 

# 1. Terminal 1: Launch Claude
claude --dangerously-skip-permissions

Ask: "Refactor commands/*.zsh to use consistent error handling"

# 2. Terminal 2: Monitor
watch -n 2 'git diff --stat'

# 3. Review when done
git diff

# 4. Commit or discard
git add -A && git commit -m "refactor: error handling"
# OR
git reset --hard HEAD

docs.title: Auto-Accept Not Working in VS Code?
docs.text:
Check 1: Are you using Claude Code extension? 

Extensions → Search "Claude Code" → Should be installed

Check 2: Is mode actually toggled? 

Look for indicator: "Auto-accept edits: ON" in chat
Try pressing Shift+Tab again

Check 3: Are you asking for edits? 

Auto-accept only works for file edits
Reads/writes/executes still prompt

docs.title: CLI Mode Not Bypassing Permissions?
docs.text:
Check 1: Using correct flag? 

# Correct
claude --dangerously-skip-permissions

# Wrong
claude --yolo               # ❌ Not a real flag
claude --skip-permissions   # ❌ Missing "dangerously"

Check 2: Using CLI, not extension? 

# Run from terminal
claude --dangerously-skip-permissions

# Not from VS Code
"Claude Code" extension panel ❌

docs.title: Still Getting Prompts?
docs.text:
VS Code Extension: This is normal - Only edits are auto-accepted - Reads, writes, executes still prompt - This is by design for safety

CLI: Check environment - Are you in a container? - Are permissions locked down? - Try in a fresh directory

docs.title: ✅ DO
docs.text:
• ✅ Use git repositories (required safety net)
  • ✅ Work on separate branches
  • ✅ Review changes frequently (git diff)
  • ✅ Start with small, low-risk tasks
  • ✅ Use worktrees for experiments
  • ✅ Keep backups before risky changes
  • ✅ Test changes before committing

docs.title: ❌ DON'T
docs.text:
• ❌ Use on production branches
  • ❌ Walk away during YOLO sessions
  • ❌ Skip reviewing changes
  • ❌ Work without git
  • ❌ Trust fake VS Code settings
  • ❌ Expect full YOLO in VS Code extension
  • ❌ Use YOLO mode with untrusted code

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
What Actually Works:

  1. VS Code: Shift+Tab → Auto-accept edits only
  2. CLI: --dangerously-skip-permissions → True YOLO mode
  3. Dev Container + CLI → Isolated YOLO environment

What Doesn't Work:

  1. ❌ claude-code.yoloMode setting (doesn't exist)
  2. ❌ Workspace file settings (no effect)
  3. ❌ --dangerously-skip-permissions in VS Code extension

Recommended Approach:

  • Interactive work: Use VS Code with Shift+Tab
  • Automated work: Use CLI with --dangerously-skip-permissions
  • Experiments: Use worktrees + CLI for safety

docs.text:

  2. Experiment with CLI in a test branch (more powerful)
  3. Set up worktrees for isolated experiments
  4. Build habits around git safety practices

docs.title: 📋 Executive Summary
docs.text:
Decision: Standardize flow-cli documentation website templates and navigation to create consistent, ADHD-friendly user experience across all content types.

Current State: - 21 documentation directories with mixed formats - Template standards exist (docs/conventions/adhd/) but not universally applied - Navigation structure varies by section - No GIF/video guidelines - Some reference cards follow template, others don't

Goal: Unified documentation experience with clear templates for: 1. Help documentation 2. Tutorials (step-by-step learning) 3. Live tutorials (interactive/video) 4. GIFs (visual demonstrations) 5. Reference cards (quick lookup) 6. Workflows (common patterns)

docs.title: 🎯 User Story
docs.text: As a flow-cli user, I want consistent documentation structure across all content types, So that I can quickly find information without learning different navigation patterns for each section.

docs.title: Acceptance Criteria
docs.text: ✅ Every content type has a defined template ✅ Navigation menus follow consistent naming patterns ✅ GIF/video guidelines established ✅ All reference cards use standard format ✅ Tutorial structure is uniform ✅ Workflow documentation follows patterns ✅ Help pages have consistent layout

docs.title: 1. Create Missing Templates
docs.text:
Action: Create standardized templates for content types lacking them

Templates to create: - TUTORIAL-TEMPLATE.md - Step-by-step learning format - WORKFLOW-TEMPLATE.md - Common pattern documentation - GIF-GUIDELINES.md - Visual content creation standards - HELP-PAGE-TEMPLATE.md - Help documentation structure

Implementation: 

cd /Users/dt/projects/dev-tools/flow-cli/docs/conventions/adhd

# Create tutorial template
cat > TUTORIAL-TEMPLATE.md <<'EOF'
# Tutorial Template

> **Use this template** for step-by-step learning tutorials

## Structure

1. **Prerequisites** (what you need first)
2. **Learning Objectives** (what you'll accomplish)
3. **Steps** (numbered, one action per step)
4. **Checkpoints** (verify progress)
5. **Next Steps** (where to go next)

## Example

See docs/tutorials/01-first-session.md
EOF

# Create workflow template
cat > WORKFLOW-TEMPLATE.md <<'EOF'
# Workflow Template

> **Use this template** for common workflow patterns

## Structure

1. **Scenario** (when to use this)
2. **Commands** (step-by-step)
3. **Expected Output** (what success looks like)
4. **Variations** (alternative approaches)
5. **Troubleshooting** (common issues)

## Example

See docs/guides/WORKFLOWS-QUICK-WINS.md
EOF

# Create GIF guidelines
cat > GIF-GUIDELINES.md <<'EOF'
# GIF Creation Guidelines

## Purpose

GIFs demonstrate visual workflows without requiring video hosting.

## Standards

- **Duration:** 5-15 seconds max
- **Size:** ≤ 2MB (optimize with gifsicle)
- **FPS:** 10-15 (smooth but small)
- **Resolution:** 1200px width max
- **Format:** .gif (not .mp4)
- **Location:** docs/assets/gifs/

## Naming Convention

`<feature>-<action>-<variant>.gif`

Examples:
- `pick-basic-usage.gif`
- `cc-dispatcher-opus-mode.gif`
- `dash-interactive-tui.gif`

## Tools

- **Record:** QuickTime Player → Export → GIF (via script)
- **Optimize:** `gifsicle -O3 --colors 128 input.gif -o output.gif`
- **Preview:** Finder Quick Look

## Embedding

\`\`\`markdown
![Description](../assets/gifs/feature-action.gif)

*Caption: Brief description of what's shown*
\`\`\`
EOF

Benefit: Clear standards for all content types

docs.title: 5. Audit and Apply Templates
docs.text:
Task: Review all existing docs, apply appropriate templates

Process:

  1. Inventory pass: 

    # Find docs without template compliance
for file in docs/**/*.md; do
    if ! grep -q "^> \*\*" "$file"; then
        echo "Missing template: $file"
    fi
done

  2. Categorize each file:

  3. Quick Start → Apply QUICK-START-TEMPLATE.md
  4. Tutorial → Apply TUTORIAL-TEMPLATE.md
  5. Workflow → Apply WORKFLOW-TEMPLATE.md
  6. Reference → Apply REFCARD-TEMPLATE.md

  7. Guide → Apply GUIDE-TEMPLATE.md (create if needed)

  8. Update iteratively:

  9. Start with most-viewed pages (index, quick-start, tutorials)
  10. Use template checklist for each update
  11. Commit per-section for reviewability

docs.title: ⚠️ Open Questions
docs.text:
1. Should "Tutorials" include videos/screencasts?
  2. Option A: Text-only tutorials, separate "Screencasts" section
  3. Option B: Embed videos directly in tutorials

  5. How to handle command docs vs reference cards?

  6. Option A: Merge into single reference section
  7. Option B: Keep separate (commands/ detailed, reference/ quick)

  8. Recommendation: Option B (serves different needs)

  9. Should we create a "Cookbook" section?

  10. Option A: Add "Cookbook" for recipes/snippets
  11. Option B: Keep recipes in Workflows

  12. Recommendation: Option B (avoid over-categorization)

  13. GIF hosting: docs/assets/ or external CDN?

  14. Option A: In-repo (docs/assets/gifs/)
  15. Option B: External hosting (GitHub LFS, CDN)
  16. Recommendation: Option A for now (< 10 GIFs), revisit at 20+

docs.title: cc wt status (~1 hour)
docs.text:
Purpose: Show all worktrees with Claude session information.

User Story: As a developer, I want to see which worktrees have active Claude sessions so I can manage my parallel work contexts.

Implementation:

# In lib/dispatchers/cc-dispatcher.zsh

_cc_worktree_status() {
    local worktree_dir="${FLOW_WORKTREE_DIR:-$(_flow_find_project_root)/.worktrees}"

    echo "🌳 Worktree Status"
    echo "━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━"

    # Get all worktrees
    git worktree list --porcelain | while read line; do
        if [[ "$line" == worktree\ * ]]; then
            local wt_path="${line#worktree }"
            local branch=$(git -C "$wt_path" branch --show-current 2>/dev/null)

            # Check for Claude session
            local session_info=""
            if [[ -f "$wt_path/.claude/session.json" ]]; then
                local last_active=$(jq -r '.last_active // empty' "$wt_path/.claude/session.json" 2>/dev/null)
                local model=$(jq -r '.model // "unknown"' "$wt_path/.claude/session.json" 2>/dev/null)
                session_info="🤖 $model (${last_active:-unknown})"
            fi

            printf "  %-30s %s\n" "$branch" "$session_info"
        fi
    done
}

Tests to add: - test_cc_wt_status_shows_worktrees - test_cc_wt_status_shows_claude_sessions - test_cc_wt_status_handles_no_sessions

docs.title: cc wt clean (~45 min)
docs.text:
Purpose: Remove worktrees for merged branches.

User Story: As a developer, I want to clean up worktrees for branches that have been merged so I don't accumulate stale directories.

Implementation:

# In lib/dispatchers/cc-dispatcher.zsh

_cc_worktree_clean() {
    local dry_run=false
    [[ "$1" == "-n" || "$1" == "--dry-run" ]] && dry_run=true

    echo "🧹 Cleaning merged worktrees..."

    # Get merged branches
    local merged_branches=$(git branch --merged dev 2>/dev/null | grep -E "^\s*feature/" | tr -d ' ')

    git worktree list --porcelain | while read line; do
        if [[ "$line" == worktree\ * ]]; then
            local wt_path="${line#worktree }"
            local branch=$(git -C "$wt_path" branch --show-current 2>/dev/null)

            if echo "$merged_branches" | grep -q "^$branch$"; then
                if $dry_run; then
                    echo "  Would remove: $wt_path ($branch)"
                else
                    echo "  Removing: $wt_path ($branch)"
                    git worktree remove "$wt_path" 2>/dev/null
                fi
            fi
        fi
    done

    # Also run g feature prune
    if ! $dry_run; then
        g feature prune
    fi
}

Integration: Combines with g feature prune for complete cleanup.

docs.title: g feature prune --force (~30 min)
docs.text:
Purpose: Skip confirmation for non-interactive use.

User Story: As a developer using CI/automation, I want to prune branches without interactive prompts.

Implementation:

# In lib/dispatchers/g-dispatcher.zsh, modify _g_feature_prune()

_g_feature_prune() {
    local force=false
    local dry_run=false
    local clean_remote=false

    # Parse flags
    while [[ $# -gt 0 ]]; do
        case "$1" in
            --force|-f) force=true; shift ;;
            -n|--dry-run) dry_run=true; shift ;;
            --all|-a) clean_remote=true; shift ;;
            *) shift ;;
        esac
    done

    # ... existing logic ...

    # Skip confirmation if force is set
    if ! $force && ! $dry_run; then
        echo -n "Delete ${#to_delete[@]} branches? [y/N] "
        read -r confirm
        [[ "$confirm" != [yY]* ]] && return 0
    fi

    # ... delete logic ...
}

docs.title: g feature prune --older-than (~1 hour)
docs.text:
Purpose: Filter branches by age.

User Story: As a developer, I want to only prune branches older than a certain age to avoid accidentally removing recent work.

Implementation:

# Add to _g_feature_prune()

# Parse duration: 30d → 30 days, 1w → 7 days, 2m → 60 days
_parse_duration() {
    local duration="$1"
    case "$duration" in
        *d) echo "${duration%d}" ;;
        *w) echo "$((${duration%w} * 7))" ;;
        *m) echo "$((${duration%m} * 30))" ;;
        *) echo "0" ;;
    esac
}

_g_feature_prune() {
    local max_age_days=0

    # Parse --older-than flag
    while [[ $# -gt 0 ]]; do
        case "$1" in
            --older-than)
                max_age_days=$(_parse_duration "$2")
                shift 2
                ;;
            # ... other flags ...
        esac
    done

    # Filter by age
    local now=$(date +%s)
    local cutoff=$((now - max_age_days * 86400))

    for branch in $merged_branches; do
        local commit_time=$(git log -1 --format=%ct "$branch" 2>/dev/null)
        if [[ $max_age_days -eq 0 ]] || [[ $commit_time -lt $cutoff ]]; then
            to_delete+=("$branch")
        fi
    done
}

Usage: 

g feature prune --older-than 30d  # Only branches > 30 days old
g feature prune --older-than 1w   # Only branches > 1 week old
g feature prune --older-than 2m   # Only branches > 2 months old

docs.title: g feature status (~45 min)
docs.text:
Purpose: Show overview of all feature branches with their status.

User Story: As a developer, I want to see which feature branches are merged, unmerged, and how old they are.

Implementation:

# In lib/dispatchers/g-dispatcher.zsh

_g_feature_status() {
    local base_branch="${1:-dev}"

    echo "📊 Feature Branch Status"
    echo "━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━"

    echo ""
    echo "🧹 Stale branches (merged to $base_branch):"
    git branch --merged "$base_branch" 2>/dev/null | while read branch; do
        branch="${branch#* }"
        [[ "$branch" == feature/* || "$branch" == hotfix/* ]] || continue
        local age=$(git log -1 --format="%cr" "$branch" 2>/dev/null)
        printf "  %-40s %s\n" "$branch" "($age)"
    done

    echo ""
    echo "⚠️  Active branches (not merged to $base_branch):"
    git branch --no-merged "$base_branch" 2>/dev/null | while read branch; do
        branch="${branch#* }"
        [[ "$branch" == feature/* || "$branch" == hotfix/* ]] || continue
        local commits=$(git rev-list --count "$base_branch".."$branch" 2>/dev/null)
        local age=$(git log -1 --format="%cr" "$branch" 2>/dev/null)
        printf "  %-40s %d commits ahead (%s)\n" "$branch" "$commits" "$age"
    done

    echo ""
    echo "💡 Tip: Run 'g feature prune' to clean up merged branches"
}

⚠️  Active branches (not merged to dev):

docs.title: wt prune (~1 hour)
docs.text:
Purpose: Combined cleanup for worktrees and branches.

User Story: As a developer, I want one command to clean up both stale worktrees and merged branches.

Implementation:

# In lib/dispatchers/wt-dispatcher.zsh

_wt_prune() {
    local branches_only=false
    local worktrees_only=false
    local dry_run=false

    while [[ $# -gt 0 ]]; do
        case "$1" in
            --branches-only) branches_only=true; shift ;;
            --worktrees-only) worktrees_only=true; shift ;;
            -n|--dry-run) dry_run=true; shift ;;
            *) shift ;;
        esac
    done

    echo "🧹 Pruning worktrees and branches..."
    echo ""

    # Prune stale worktrees
    if ! $branches_only; then
        echo "Pruning stale worktrees..."
        if $dry_run; then
            git worktree prune --dry-run
        else
            git worktree prune
        fi
    fi

    # Prune merged branches
    if ! $worktrees_only; then
        echo ""
        echo "Pruning merged branches..."
        if $dry_run; then
            g feature prune -n
        else
            g feature prune --force
        fi
    fi

    echo ""
    echo "✅ Cleanup complete"
}

Usage: 

wt prune                  # Clean both worktrees and branches
wt prune --branches-only  # Only clean branches
wt prune --worktrees-only # Only clean worktrees
wt prune -n               # Dry run

    local total_size=0

    git worktree list --porcelain | while read line; do
        if [[ "$line" == worktree\ * ]]; then
            local wt_path="${line#worktree }"
            local branch=$(git -C "$wt_path" branch --show-current 2>/dev/null || echo "detached")
            local size=$(du -sh "$wt_path" 2>/dev/null | cut -f1)
            local status=""

            # Check if branch is merged
            if git branch --merged dev 2>/dev/null | grep -q "$branch"; then
                status="🧹 merged"
            elif [[ ! -d "$wt_path/.git" && ! -f "$wt_path/.git" ]]; then
                status="⚠️  stale"
            else
                status="✅ active"
            fi

            printf "  %-30s %-10s %-6s %s\n" "$branch" "$status" "$size" "$wt_path"
        fi
    done

    echo ""
    echo "💡 Run 'wt prune' to clean up stale worktrees"
}

docs.title: Bug Fix: Math Expression Error in _proj_show_git_status
docs.text: Date: 2025-12-31 Reported by: User via /craft:code:debug Status: ✅ Fixed

docs.title: Problem Summary
docs.text:
The pick command crashed with a "bad math expression" error when navigating to certain worktree directories:

_proj_show_git_status:10: bad math expression: operator expected at `Terminal R...'

docs.title: Root Cause
docs.text:
The _proj_show_git_status() function extracts modified and untracked file counts using:

local modified=$(git -C "$dir" diff --name-only 2>/dev/null | wc -l | tr -d ' ')
local untracked=$(git -C "$dir" ls-files --others --exclude-standard 2>/dev/null | wc -l | tr -d ' ')

In certain environments (likely involving terminal control codes, prompt interference, or locale-specific wc output), the wc -l command can return:

  • Non-numeric output (e.g., "Terminal Running...")
  • Output with embedded whitespace or control characters
  • Empty strings

When these malformed values are used in arithmetic comparisons:

if [[ $modified -gt 0 || $untracked -gt 0 ]]; then

ZSH throws: bad math expression: operator expected at ...

docs.title: Solution
docs.text:
Added input sanitization to ensure $modified and $untracked are always valid integers:

# Ensure numeric values (sanitize any potential non-numeric output)
# Strip whitespace and default to 0 if empty or non-numeric
modified="${modified##*( )}"    # Remove leading spaces
modified="${modified%%*( )}"    # Remove trailing spaces
untracked="${untracked##*( )}"
untracked="${untracked%%*( )}"
[[ "$modified" =~ ^[0-9]+$ ]] || modified=0
[[ "$untracked" =~ ^[0-9]+$ ]] || untracked=0

docs.title: How it works:
docs.text:
1. Strip leading/trailing whitespace using ZSH parameter expansion
  2. Validate the value matches the regex ^[0-9]+$ (one or more digits)
  3. Default to 0 if validation fails

docs.title: Why This Happened
docs.text:
• Assumption: We assumed wc -l | tr -d ' ' always returns clean numeric output
  • Reality: Terminal environments can inject control codes, prompts, or other garbage into command output

docs.title: Similar Issues to Watch For
docs.text:

docs.title: Zoxide (Frecency-based Jump)
docs.text:
Installed: ✅ Homebrew (brew install zoxide) Speed: 10-40x faster than old z plugin (Rust-based)

Command Description Example z <dir> Jump to directory z medfit zi <dir> Interactive fzf selection zi med za <dir> Manually add to database za ~/special/path z - Jump to previous directory z - zoxide query <term> Query database zoxide query med

How it works:

  • Tracks directories you visit (automatically)
  • Uses "frecency" algorithm: frequency + recency
  • Learns your habits over time
  • Integrates with fzf for interactive selection

Examples:

# Jump to most frequent/recent match
$ z medfit        # Jumps to ~/projects/r-packages/active/medfit

# Partial matches work
$ z med           # Smart: likely goes to medfit

# Interactive mode (if multiple matches)
$ zi med          # Shows fzf menu to choose

# Add manually (rare, usually automatic)
$ za ~/some/deep/path

Combined Workflows:

# Use @ bookmarks for main areas, zoxide for deep navigation
$ @rpkg           # Jump to r-packages (bookmark)
$ z robust        # Then zoxide to medrobust (frecency)

# Quick return
$ z -             # Go back to previous directory

docs.title: Direnv (Auto Environment Loader)
docs.text:
Installed: ✅ Homebrew (brew install direnv) Purpose: Automatically load/unload environment per directory

Setup per project:

# Create .envrc in project root
cd ~/projects/r-packages/active/medfit
cat > .envrc << 'EOF'
export R_LIBS_USER=~/R/medfit-libs
export RENV_ACTIVE=TRUE
layout python3  # Optional: auto venv
EOF

# Allow direnv to load it (one-time per project)
direnv allow

# Now whenever you cd into medfit, these env vars load automatically!

Common use cases:

# R package with custom library
export R_LIBS_USER=~/R/project-libs
source renv/activate.R

# Node project
export NODE_ENV=development
export API_KEY=$(security find-generic-password -a "$USER" -s api_key -w)

# Python project
layout python3

# Claude MCP project
export MCP_DEBUG=true
export LOG_LEVEL=debug

ADHD Benefits:

  • Zero mental load - environments "just work"
  • No more "did I activate renv?"
  • No more "is the right PATH set?"
  • Automatic cleanup when leaving directory

docs.title: Phase 1: Core pick Command (Context-Aware)
docs.text:
pick() {
    # Detect context
    local context=""

    # Check if in R package
    if [[ -f "DESCRIPTION" ]] && grep -q "^Package:" DESCRIPTION 2>/dev/null; then
        context="rpkg"
    # Check if in git repo
    elif git rev-parse --git-dir > /dev/null 2>&1; then
        context="git"
    # Check if in projects
    elif [[ "$PWD" == "$HOME/projects"* ]]; then
        context="projects"
    fi

    # Show context-appropriate picker
    case "$context" in
        rpkg)
            # R package context: pick R file, test, vignette, or .STATUS
            echo "📦 R Package Context - What to pick?"
            echo "1) R file"
            echo "2) Test file"
            echo "3) Vignette"
            echo "4) .STATUS"
            read -r choice
            case "$choice" in
                1) pick-file ;;
                2) pick-test ;;
                3) pick-vignette ;;
                4) pick-status ;;
            esac
            ;;
        git)
            # Git context: pick branch, view diff, etc.
            echo "🔀 Git Repo - What to pick?"
            echo "1) Switch branch"
            echo "2) Review changes"
            echo "3) Browse commits"
            read -r choice
            # ... handle choices
            ;;
        projects)
            # Projects context: pick project or package
            echo "📁 Projects - What to pick?"
            echo "1) Project"
            echo "2) R Package"
            echo "3) .STATUS file"
            read -r choice
            # ... handle choices
            ;;
        *)
            # Default: show all options
            echo "🔍 What to pick?"
            echo "1) Project"
            echo "2) R Package"
            echo "3) .STATUS file"
            read -r choice
            # ... handle choices
            ;;
    esac
}

docs.title: Phase 2: Subcommands
docs.text:
pick() {
    local subcommand="${1:-}"

    case "$subcommand" in
        file|files)      pick-file ;;
        test|tests)      pick-test ;;
        vignette|vig)    pick-vignette ;;
        status)          pick-status ;;
        hub)             pick-hub ;;
        project|proj)    pick-project ;;
        package|pkg)     pick-package ;;
        "")              pick-interactive ;;  # No args = interactive
        *)
            echo "❌ Unknown: pick $subcommand"
            echo "Usage: pick [file|test|vignette|status|hub|project|package]"
            return 1
            ;;
    esac
}
